text: Bottle from Sainsbury at Machester Piccadilly railway station. Poured dark brown with an average sized off-white to beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, light coffee, dark fruits and alcohol. Toward heavy sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation.
An old ale with sweet stout flavours. Forward alcohol and a nice colour and head. However it really wasnt my thing.

Appearance: Very dark brown, almost black. Some light tan head.
Aroma: Dark fruit, prunes, dark malt. Roasted.
Taste: Dark malt, dark fruit, smooth.
Bought: Sainsburys, 500 ml, GBP ?.??
Info: 1/1-2017, BB: 8/6-2018
Nice dark ale although a little overpowering its a good example of this genre ok

Superowe piwo. W starym dobrym stylu. Ciemna brazowa barwa niemal czarne prawie nie ma przeswitu. Bardzo niewielkie refleksy czerwieni. Piana o atramentowym odcieniu, puszysta i gruba, sredniej wielkosci ale bardzo trwala. Zapach likierowego alkoholu i goracej czekolady. W smaku na poczatku likierowa slodycz, cos jakby porto i polewa czekoladowo-krowkowa na ciescie w ktorym jest mnostwo borowek i jagod. A wiec spora mieszanka ciemnych granatowych owocow, deserowa czekolada i uderzenie alkoholu szlachetnego. Po chwili po przelknieciu posmak slodyczy powoli ustepuje a alkohol blyskawicznie ustepuje tworzac rozgrzewajaca koncowke z lekka nute chmielowosci i palonego slodu. Bardzo zlozone i ciekawe piwo.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2016 500ml bottle from Sainsburys. Pours black with a three-finger beige head. Aroma: chocolate and fruity malt. Taste: chocolate, ripe dark fruits, malt, slight warming spice/alcohol. Rich and complex. Oily/creamy texture, soft carbonation, medium body. Lovely stuff.

Pours dark red to black with medium carbonation, good lacing and an off-white head.

Aroma is strong. Plums, burnt caramel, apricot, prunes and orange. Taste is sweet with bitterness in a long, if thin, finish.

Proper English strong ale.

Very dark brown, long lasting high beige head. Aroma chocolate, dried plums, raisins, butterscotch. Palate medium to low, higher carbonation. Taste prune jam, cloves, dry and sour finish. Not ahint of chocolate despite the aroma, but that of coffee instead. Quite nice, original beer.

Bottle. Thinnish dark ruby with lovely creamy head and lacing. Stone fruit and malt aroma. Chocolate and sweet malts, hoppy medium bitterness and some warming spice coming through. Really not boozy at all. Lovely if a touch thin.

This is the kind of perfectly good British beer that helps you remember why you ever liked British beer in the first place, and that a beer doesnt always have to be hop forward to be flavorful and tasty. Also, this is pro level stuff. I mean by that: it starts with a sweet dark malt front, but its more of a molasses type sugariness (where molasses itself isnt actually very sweet). There are virtually no hop flavors or aromas, but there is a mild spicy bitterness to balance out the finish, but mostly the balance achieved by the fact that the beer is fermented out to a semi-dryness, so its never cloying and thus it doesnt actually need a hop wallop to tame it. Amazingly light and drinkable for the relatively higher ABV. Only complaint is cosmetic, it was dark, cola-like, with minimal head - though the lower carbonation did wonders for the maltier body.

500ml bottle. Colour is near black. Short head atop. Aroma has smoky, plummy, blackberry fruity character. Taste is those same elements. Nice fruitiness throughout. A little old-world in its execution. Would make a nice fireside sipper.

Bottle from Sainsburys supermarket. Pours a deep brown colour, lovely red hints and a slight tan head. Interesting aroma: slightly earthy, malty and sweet lactic, buttery hints. Slightly sweet to taste with a firm bitterness to follow. Superbly balanced, peppery hop, firmly malty and slightly metallic (iodine?) with a good dry finish. Complex, rich and rewarding.

Ciemno brazowe w barwie z srednia palona piana. W zapachu czuc alkohol (7.3 procenta) i owoce z czekolada. Smak wszystko wynagradza. Osobiscie sadze ze przypomina Amber Kozlaka ale to moja opina. Zatem: Slodowy posmak z owocami czekolada rodzynkami troche chlebowy- wszystko dobrane bardzo harmonijnie. Dla mnie jedno z lepszych...i nie zapomnijmy o slowach Bergmana na kapslu

Bottle from Sainsburys. Dark brown body with a medium beige head. Good lacing. Aroma of tea, earth, wood and raisin. Flavour of filter coffee, milk chocolate and plum. Medium body with a creamy texture. Soft fizz. Subtle and luxurious - tastes lighter than 7.3% ABV.

Beautiful beer, lightly roasted, chocolate, beautiful head. Palate is creamy and lovely. Really nice beer.

gift from uckelman

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe - Near black body with a beige top. Entertainingly complex nose picks out coffee, chocolate, liquorice, with dark berries and some floral notes and a good deal of smokiness. Flavours are led by liquorice, sweet raisins and cola with roast coffee and spices. Nice syrupy body made it a well rounded and balanced Christmas Pudding of a beer! Nice.

Bottle from Sainsburys, drunk at home. Black, smoky and impenetrable. Wisps of khaki head. Woodsmoke, plum pudding, caramel. Sweet smoky taste with a surprising saltiness. Salted caramel, taffy, biltong, and stone fruit aftertaste. Full palate, slightly over-carbonated but I can live with that. This is truly exemplary and the best beer you are likely to find in a supermarket.

500ml bottle. Nearly black in color with a fading tan head leaving a ring. Big roasty chocolate molasses toffee aroma. The flavor is great, dry and restrained with hidden chocolate sweetness. Ashy as if you were sucking on your old grampys pipe (dont read too much into that). Bitter on the finish. Medium full body with soft carbonation. An elegant, unique, and enjoyable brewski on the whole.
UPDATED: AUG 29, 2015 (500ml) this dark ale is like a metaphorical blowjob from a beautiful dark woman . she loves u ,but we will never marry . beautiful silky liasion.
Pours a black colour with a big head. Taste is candy like with some liqourice and roast malts. Good

Pours clear, very dark brown. Coffee-creamer colored head, fine bubbles. Not much aroma. Very light yet slightly oily body. I can definitely taste the chocolate malt in this one. Palette is outstanding.
Dark opaque brown with small tan head of varying-sized bubbles. Not much aroma. Thick, rich, spicy, oily, molasses-y, a little bit bitter on the end. This is excellent.
Bottle received as a gift. Pours a lovely deep brown/black colour with a creamy head. Luxurious flavours of roasted nuts - a surprisingly easy drinker for a 7.3% beer. Beautiful.

Bottle from Cellar Door, Four Oaks.

Pours dark brown, black in colour with a 2 finger just off white head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, toffee, touches of molasses. Taste of initial chocolate, then fruits, dark fruits, plums, raisins, cherries, winter beer really. Following the fruits you get some creaminess, more chocolate, a touch of coffee, some sugary sweetness too. A nice warming finish to it too. Very good brew!

Quality ale from j w lees bottle at home pours dark brown messy tan head tastes date and plum with a warm alcoholic glow smells of rich booze lovely mouth feel a real winner some port note would go well with cheese love this beer
500ml bottle. Pours black with a foamy tan head. Not much aroma, some malt and a little metallic. Taste is great, malt, coffee, chocolate and a hint of liquorice

Pours a porter/stout color with not much head. Very weak dark fruit aroma, sweet. Taste is sweet malts and dark fruit. Overall a really drinkable beer that I enjoyed. Lower rating is mostly due to lack of aroma.

Almost black in color , medium-sized off-white head. Aroma of caramel , chocolate , berries , some vanilla. Rich taste of raisins , chocolate , caramel, toffee , fruits. Smooth , warming aftertaste. I didn't expect such a good beer!

500 mL bottle bought at Sainsbury. Very dark with a decent foamy head. Lots of malt, in the aroma, I like! Nice deep malty flavour with great body, overall a well rounded beer. Good stuff that could make you think it was a doppelbock if you were served it in Germany. Didnt think we made beers like this in England but Im glad we do.

Struggling old school breweries could learn an awful from Lees and Manchester Star Ale. Instead of being all trendy hipster geeky going back to old recipes and have produced this absolute beauty. Dark to black with reddish highlights the nose is old school but its the long complex flavour is just divine. Dark chocolate, plum, spice and dark fruit wrapped in a suave silky classy glove. Devine, and everything which Old Peculier should be but isnt. Love it.

500 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 10/27/2010. Pours nearly opaque dark brown color with a 1-2 finger dense tan head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big molasses, caramel, toast, toffee, brown bread, chocolate, raisin, plum, light cocoa, light nuttiness, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt and fruity yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of big molasses, caramel, toast, toffee, brown bread, chocolate, cocoa, raisin, plum, light nuttiness, and yeast/roasted earthiness. Light earthy herbal/roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of chocolate, cocoa, caramel, toast, brown bread, toffee, molasses, raisin, plum, and yeast/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt and fruity/earthy yeast flavors; with a great malt/yeast balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth, creamy, and lightly slick/chalky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an outstanding English porter style. All around awesome balance, complexity, and robustness of dark/bready malt and fruity/earthy yeast flavors; and very smooth to drink for the ABV. This held up very well for its age considering the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

A dark red tinged brown coloured beer with a latte coloured head. A dark malt aroma, treacle, dark chocolate, nutty, woody and vanilla spice. Dry mouthfeel. A bittersweet taste, smooth malty flavours, treacle, chocolate, woody vanilla spice, then a mild bitterness in the background that comes from a fruity hop flavour. The finish is dry, but smooth and chocolatey.

Mahogany brown with 5mm of medium-coarse yellowish tan head. Moderate rate of decay. Aroma is light caramel, roasted blackberry, lightly salted dough. Body is oily, slightly watery/gritty. Very light carbonation, soft. Flavor is light light caramel, salted and mild dough, bread. Very clean. light pear. Great English strong ale, I love how clean it is and the doughy breadiness. Yum!!

Bottle from Crafty Pint in Darlington. 
Appearance - black olive in colour and general shininess. Big fawn head. 
Nose - treacle sponge with light burnt orange note. 
Taste - marmalade then liquorice. Slightly nutty too. 
Palate - medium bodied with a big dry and tangy texture and a dry finish. Actually it does slightly fall off a cliff at the end. 
Overall - yeah good beer which drinks easily for the big ABV.

Pours an opaque dark brown similar to a stout, but not black. Well below average head, lacing and retention. Outstanding nose of dark fruit (plum, fig), sweet chocolate, slightly burnt molasses and just a hint of alcohol. The nose is similar to that of an Olde or Scott Ale, but lighter - as is the flavor profile. Light medium body with a hint of slickness. Normal carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the finish. The outstanding flavor profile is reasonably intense, very complex and masterfully balanced. The beginning to middle is a blend of flavors that slowly fade allowing subsequent identification. All flavors of the nose are present and basically cascade from burnt molasses to dark fruit and then into a light bitterness followed by a chocolate note and associated sweetness. The finish is a slow fade of malty sweetness with a hint of alcohol and a bit of hop and alcohol bite.
bottle a black colored beer with a white head aroma malts caramel citrus fruits coffee and hops flavor malts citrus spicy coffee chocolate and hops
500ml bottle from Sainsburys. Deep dark colour with tan head. Aroma has sweet malts the taste has this too, with roasted malts a touch of chocolate.

Bottle from Brewery webshop. It pours darkest brown/nr black with a small tan head. The nose is vinous, dark fruits, berry, fruit compote, light roast, treacle, some acidity and candy. The taste is rich, smooth, jammy berry, dark fruit, roasted malt, light spice, earth, cocoa, vinous, boiled sweets, candy cane, some bitterness, earth, wood and astringency with a lingering dry finish. Full body and moderate carbonation. Great depth of flavour. All comes together rather well. Impressive stuff.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Pours mahogany with a thin tan head. The taste is toffee, liquorice coffee and a fair bit of spice. Really good traditional English beer. Full of flavour and really drinkable. Excellent.

Mocha and licorice on first sniff with coffee and chicory, dark chocolate, prunes on the second go. Lovely smooth mouth feel and strong coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruit on the palate. Dry bittersweet aftertaste. Doesnt really drink like a 7.3. A sweeter interpretation of the porter style? Like it very much and Im a real hop head!

500ml bottle from Sainsburys, poured into tulip glass, sampled at room temperature. Very dark with red tinge, fairly tight head, estery aromas with tinned prunes and roast barley. Big mouthfeel, with lots of fruity, caramelly malts and Christmas pud, balanced by an almost stout-like bitterness, giving a long, satisfying finish: a mighty brew that deserves wider recognition.

500ml bottle. Dark brown colour with reddish tinge, foamy tan head leaving lacing and aroma of malt, chocolate, dried fruit. Taste is sweet malty, with brown sugar, chocolate, raisins, some spice & bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, lingering chocolate and light bitter at the finish. Very drinkable.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Deep brown colour, quite high carbonation. Initial taste is quite sweet, I guess I was expecting a more upfront hop bitterness from the old recipe. Actually settles down to be reasonably well balanced. Malty, some tobacco, molasses, fruity. Just enough hop to keep it drinkable, spicy, maybe more Goldings would have been a winner here. Drinks very easily for the abv. Overall, pretty good.
Bottle shared with McTapps. Pouring in really dark with medium head. Chocolate nose with a touch oft coffee and sugar. Mild and warming taste with lots of chocolate, some sugar and plums. Delicious.

Bottle bought at Sainsburys in Folkestone. Pours out in a deep dark brown colour with low head and smooth body. Aroma of plums, straw and barley. Taste of chocolate, mild milky coffee, mild barley, cake, butter, fudge, rum and wine. Wonderful complex taste with a warming finish. Enjoyed it a lot.

Aroma: intense bread malts, caramel, chocolate, dark ripe fruits, prunes. Appearance: dark brown, medium creamy beige head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: sweets intensify quickly, massive malts, delicious bread, caramel, chocolate, toasted flavours, very light bitters appearing in the background. Overall: this is an amazing English Strong Ale, delicious and very complex aroma and flavours - get it for 2 pounds at Sainsburys!. Bottle from Sainsburys, Pimlico.
Bottle from Millets Farm Store. Chocolate on the nose. Taste of chocolate, fruits and meat brooth. Lean mouthfeel but also dry.
Bottle from sainsburys. Tasting with Richthevillan. Black beer with small tan head. Aroma of chocolate and fruity. Taste is dark fruits, chocolate and some earth. Very good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from Sainsburys via SarkyNorthener; dark chestnut brown pour with a quickly disappearing tan head, caramel sweet aroma, taste has chocolate, dark berries, roast malts, caramel, smooth tasting, very good.

Bottle at home from notes. Pours dark brown in color with a large beige head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit, a hint of smoke, molasses and a touch of earth. This one surprised me a bit. Just a bitthin at the finish.
Bottle from sainsburys. Dark reddish brown ale with a sturdy tan head. Sweet dark malts and nutty aroma. Sweet and strong alcohol taste. Good smooth mouthfeel.

Hidden Gem, this one. Old mans Manc back street boozer frequented by Mark E Smith shares a pint with the Beastie Boys. JWL and Brooklyn Brewery collab. To paraphrase Alan Partridge, wipe the prejudice juice off your lips. Stick a Mikkeller label on it and youd pay 4 times as much.Truly wonderful beer.

Bottle at home. Dark almost black brown with a medium grey / pale tan head. Aroma of tobacco, fruit, dash of licorice. Flavour is a little fruity, medium sweetness, nice lick of alcohol strength which I usually like and did. I like it. Its nice. A pleasant surprise, not all JW Lees beers appeal to me.

Fruity nose with a lighter body than expected. Sweet chocolate, earthy, coffee. Strong Ale maybe mislead me a little, like a porter but more ephemeral. Flavor fades pretty quick, but leaves a sticky residue on the lips. Very nice beer. I will buy again.

500 ml bottle poured into tulip-style English pint. Near black color with a fleeting light tan head that quickly melts away to a thin film. Strong toffee and molasses aroma. Flavor follows suit, with a smooth drinkability. This tastes quintessentially English to me.

Bottle. Deep brown body is capped by a small, loose beige head that is gone quickly. Nose has licorice, roast, and bittersweet chocolate. Moderately sweet and bitter. . Flavor is much like the nose with some sweeter malt. Medium body and a bit thin. Finishes with both light roast and sweetness. Nice.
Bought cheap from Sainsburys. Didnt expect much of this, but its really good. Super smooth and packed with flavour: leather, ashtray, mulled fruit, malty dark choc. Excellent.

Bottle. Poured a deep ruby colour with a dense beige head. Aroma of molasses, dark malts and some tobacco. Smooth dark fruit sweetness, some prunes and dates mixed with light roasted bitterness. Finish faded out slightly, some residual black treacle sweetness mixed with light coffee bitterness.

Bottle. Raisin aroma with some sugary notes. Minimal head. Brown color. Initial taste is a bit chewy but that seems to fade quicky and dry out moderately thin. Kind of plain. Solid for beer but just underwhelming when I think of English string ales.
Clear dark brown pour. Faint aroma, some dark fruit and sweetness. Malty chewy dark fruit caramel and more chewy.
Rom 606 Premier Inn Victoria, Manchester 24 Jan 13. Ultradyprød / svart. Lavt - litt farget skum. Søt plommearoma. Smaken er søt frukt & plommer. Blir raskt litt syrlig.

Bottle - Very Dark Brown (almost Black) in colour with a Reddish tinge. Very Malty; roasty malts, dark chocolate, caramel, coffee, nuts, hint of tobacco. Fruity; ripe fruits and berries, raisins, plums, hint of oranges. Hoppy; understated bitterness. Lightly spiced. Smooth. Alcohol well hidden. Sweetish roast malty fruity throughout with a dry finish. More like a Baltic porter in strength. Liked this a lot. Lovely Porter!

Both sweet and smoky. This is a bit of shock, some coffee and chocolate going on with this. Dates and prunes fruity and then you get this herbal/vegetable fennel kick. I was not expecting much from this but it was great. 2013.08.03

Appearance: Dark ruby/brown with 3 finger tan head.
Aroma: Bread, dried fruit, slightly vinous, chocolate, liquorice and grassy.
Taste: Medium sweet and bitterness, low sourness.
Palate: Thick smooth texture, light body, average carbonation, lingering, fairly dry bitter/sweet malty fruity finish which becomes more sour at the end.
Comments: Tasty.

Aroma of a hot chocolate brownie, with almond, vanilla, and licorice. Very dark brown. Lots of dark sweet malt taste, chocolate aftertaste. Noticeably strong. Body is thinner than most porter, filling yet deceptively smooth. Tall dark and bloody English.

11th September 2013Opaque dark brown beer with a good tan head. Smooth malt, a little cream. Its run through with minerally carbonation. Whispers of marmite, toffee and a little spice. Finishes smooth. A superior malty beer.

Bottle. Poured a deep black colour with a short lived head. Alcohol is very prominent as you might expect from a 7.3% beer. I got caramel with a hint of bubblegum and roast coffee in the mouth. A lovely warming swallow makes this beer one to drink on a dark, windy autumn evening. How much the taste owes to the 1884 recipe or the involvement of Garret Oliver is an interesting question.
Bottle. Looks good. Lots of malty goodness - chocolate, liquorice, coffee, dark fruits, nuts. Warming alcohol on the finish.

A nice medium brown body, slightly opaque with an off white head. Aroma was a mix of chocolate malts and some roasted malts. Mild hop presence. Initial flavor had a nice sweet flavor, which gave way to a nice and bitter flavor which came from the malts and a nice roasted flavor. It was clearly different from a stout, but it did have some familiar characteristics. Finish was slightly dry, but mostly smooth. Easy to drink.

500ml bottle drunk on the train gazing out at sheep, and a few cows. Some horses too I think. But mostly sheep. For some reason I always thought beer in 1884 tasted like bitter mud. If this is anything to go by Ive been a bit mislead. No wonder they drank so much of the stuff back then. Dark fruits, mild bitterness and a fruitness that bubbles to the front while chocolate malt embers burn quietly at the back. Quite an alcohol kick as well at 7.3%. Very nice beer.
Bottle from Sainsburys via Joneso. Dark reddish black with a sweet fruitcake aroma. Taste is sweet - but not too sweet - grassy malt with licorice. Drinkable for the ABV.

Pours a rich deep caramel color with a finger or two of eggshell foam. The nose is round with soft toffee, taffy, caramel and a trace of grass and cocoa dust. Palate is full and rich and follows the nose nicely with a great fuzzy carbonation that dries out nicely on the back end with a bit of bitterness to keep it clean and enjoyable !
Deep brown body, medium sized light tan head, spotty lacing. Caramel, toffee, chocolate, light nuttiness, and tobacco. Medium bodied, lively carbonation, light bitterness, earthy, light bitterness.

Nose is slight hop, toast, slight smoke, a slightly displeasing metallic note. Taste is sweet, light chocolate, blackcurrant, licorice, cola a touch of lemon leading to a suprisingly delicate sweet malt finish with a slight undercut. Taste is a little thin. Mouthfeel is not thick enough for me. 

A reasonable beer which does not do much for me in the bottle. I would like to try it draft.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2015 
August 2013 500ml brown bottle from Sainsburys. Absolutely love it. This is my kind of beer. Im going back for some more. Good malt flavours, with a touch of Port. Soft, creamy mouthfeel. Pleasant rough edge from the hops. Not assertive - just added for interest and balance. The main game is the malt. [4.5]
August 2015 I now understand how Dandelion & Burdock and Sarsaparilla developed as Temperance Movement substitutes for beer. Thick and malty and gorgeous. A little bit like Old Engine Oil. This is 7.3%? Fuck me, but its gorgeously drinkable!  [4.5]

Bottle. bb 29 july 2014. pours a dark brown, pretty dense. treacly dark toffee aroma. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Very sweet, treacly, choc, touch of coffee, rich sweet malt loaf, booze. Bit of citrusy stuff at the finish. Nice.
Poured from a bottle it is a dark brown with a slight tan head the aroma is malty and the taste is of coffee and chocolate and lingers on the palate
From a 50 cl bottle shared at home. Pours black with a tan head. Caramel and dark fruit nose. Flavors of dark cherries, plums and toffee. Very full bodied. A bit of a lingering alcohol finish. Tasty.
So suprisingly good and awesome! I love Porters but this one was secretly pretending to be an ale. I want more!

Chilled 500ml bottle with three days to go before its BBD: poured into an Abbot Ale glass tankard at home on 1st Aug 2013.

Looked great: lovely dark body with a huge tanned head of large bubbles, smooth foaming top to the head.

Dry but malty nose and taste: bitterness comes through from the start. Mild burnt feel to the flavour, but not overpowering. Dark chocolate and young Port came to mind mid-tasting, very nice!

Really impressed: full of interesting flavours and although my palate is on the sweet side this beer still hit the spot for me.

It is warm and sunny outside as I drink and write this: even though this is a coal fire and winter brew in my eyes, it can also be taken during the summer months.

opaque mahogany with a thin beige head. soft medium-full body with medium carbonation.

aroma: dark fruit, soy sauce, mushrooms, leafy hops, sweet pale malt, char, and tobacco.

taste: sweet roasted malt, carob, licorice, cola, biscuits, subtle apple/pear esters, and a touch of diacetyl.

luscious and flavorful with a perfectly delicate balance, everything comes through but nothing has prominence. quite simple, yet wonderfully complex and deep. the yeast strain seems to contribute greatly to the mouthfeel and the complexity and the balance.

this beer on cask, or very lightly carbonated and pushed through a stout faucet would be outstanding, maybe even with a bit of licorice root tossed in the cask.

16.9oz bottle, shared by Dan H. Very dark brown, but clear color. Little khaki head. Few loose dots of lace. Good dark chocolatey, roasty nose. Little licorice, good earthy herbal floral hop. Moderate sweet taste, lightly spicy. Medium-plus body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation. Lightly dry in the finish, just a light hint of spicy bite. Good stuff. Unique and interesting. Kind of stout-like and hoppy. [Couldnt pinpoint what style this was supposed to be at the time. If its a porter, its a very unusual porter!]

7/14/13. 500mL bottle from Beachs in Destin. Deep brown pour, almost black, with a small khaki head that fades. Boozy dark fruits on the aroma, English ale yeast, plus, plenty of caramel and nuts. Rich burnt caramel on the flavor with dark fruits and nuttiness. Rich but smooth with a dry, bitter finish. Tasty.
Poured a medium to dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of roast malt, dark chocolate. some coffee. Medium body, flavour as the aroma, quite bitter but a bit watery on the throughput.
Bottle shared at Deans sticky table tasting. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and fruit. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle at the Deansos monthly RB tasting, July 2013. Poured a dark mahogany with a frothy tan head and some broken lace. The aroma is weak dry malt leading to a medium bitter, malty, weak, mild like watery flavour. A decent beer, but I cant understand the high rating.
Pours almost Black. Aroma is chocolate, weak coffee and some lemon. Medium body with light carbonation. Not so good.

Bottled ; Devon ; UK ; Malt,chocolate,roasted and fruity aroma ; Very dark brown color with smaller lasting head ; Sweeter taste with long bitter finish ; Medium body ; Nicely balanced ; Superb porter.

Leading off with almost no head, I catch the aroma of biscuit, raisin, hard water, more dark fruits and leather. Taste is astringent, deep dark fruits, chocolate, and some leathery tobacco and bread foundation that is awesome. A little plum and cordial alcohol on the finish. Smooth medium mouthfeel. Great Porter.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a tan head that leaves a few spots.  Nose is peanut and coffee with hints of caramel and smoke.  Milky medium body with a tang.  Taste is French roast, chicory, carob and Dr. Pepper.  Finishes dry and bitter with black licorice.  Its got that iconic feel but pales to the newer brews.
A beery beacon of light shone out  bank of cardboard beers, and lo! Twas the kind of beer youd expect to pay a fiver for from some up and coming craft brewer, not two quid in Sainsburys.
500ml bottle shared - cheers Steven! Pours dark brown with thin white head. Smells of stone fruit and sugar. Tastes a bit too sweet to me. No discernible hops at all. Bit disappointing.
Bottle. Pours a black colour with a beige head, rich malty aroma, the taste is soft and has a light bitter taste with fruit with a dry finish.

Very interesting mix of things in the aroma. On the surface its tootsie roll chocolate and prunes, but then theres vanilla, pipe tobacco, treacle and marzipan. Despite complexity, still seems a bit sweet and almost reminds me of black cherry soda pop when its cold. As it warms a more umami soy sauce like flavor develops.

500 ml sampled in 2009. Dark reddish brown body with a big, creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavor has light roasted, dark malt, chocolate, dry fruit and hint of warming alcohol. Fine body, good aftertaste and a god balance. Very nice porter.

50cl bottle.
Thick off white head.   clear black pour.  lovely smooth chocolate notes.  Nice and smooth.

500ml bottle from Sainsbury. Pours black with big but short lived beige head. Smells of tobacco and dark fruit. Tastes of plum,  prunes,  chocolate and tobacco.  Nice bitter finish after all the sweetness.

bottle.  mostly clear cola colored body with a short tan head.  the roast provides a powdery chocolate aroma with only a slight roasted-husk resemblance.  lightly dusty / earthy and mossy English ale yeast.  plum esters and nutty and toasty pale malt.  sweet, toasty, a tad chalky / husky, medium-low bitterness, moderate acidity. early on its a bit watery and fizzy for its size, but as it warms it really starts to come together - rich cookie crumb toasty malt with a quietly lush and full malt mouthfeel.

Almost no head and basic blackish brown for pour. Very sweet Chocolate toffee malt taste. Very smooth and creamy with almost no hop. I have never had porter this sweet and complex in taste and aroma before love it to death!!!.

50cl bottle pours a watery, mostly opaque mahogany brown with ruby edges and some creamy, beige head.  Aroma is almost like a Belgian dubbel, candy sugar, molasses, bread, tons of dried fruit, prune, raisin, dried pears, some rum, some port wine.  Flavor is sweet and malty, just tons of dried fruit, dried cherry, dried apples, raisins, prunes, candy sugar.  Lightly sweet finish, drinkable.  I cant remember a beer that had more of a dried fruit flavor than this.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2015 Oct 2012 - 500ml bottle at home.  Murky brown pour. Smells a bit like a club - feet, ale and background sick. Tastes mild, no bitterness, bit watery, some sweetness. Mild, with not a great deal of flavour. The flavour that can be detected isnt great. (2.2)
Aug 2015 -  Some people rave about this beer, so I thought I better give it a second chance.  500ml, 7.3%, BB Dec 2015, drunk at home a couple of weeks ago.  Aroma is cola, sasparilla and liquorice.  Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation.  Taste is sweet and sugary, cola, tangy sweet, a bit yeasty.  No - its just not for me. Its like a yeasty, dirty cola.  (2.6)
Very dark porter with no head.  Has a mild roasted aroma, some of which is in its flavour too.  Mild and smooth in the palate with a bit of a fizz.

Bottle. Lustrous dark brown with mahogany highlights. Roasty aroma, slightly sweet. Silky roasted malts with complex nuances in the spirit of pipe tobacco, prunes, bitter chocolate, light anise. Very tasty and balanced with a velvety mouthfeel. Loved it.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle. Roasty malt, prune, chocolate, and light anise aroma. Deep chestnut with a small tan head. Roasty malt, anise, and dark fruit, and light chocolate flavor with a bitter hop finish. Medium to full body, moderate carbonation. Very nice.

Bouteille 500ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry ou Blankboy. De couleur brune-noire et quasi-opaque. Nez de malt rôti, sucré et aux notes terreuses, léger de caramel toffee, de mélasse, de houblon terreux, de noix rôties avec des notes fruitées (figues, notes de raisins et de cerises) et de chocolat noir. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-bas ainsi quune texture riche et sirupeuse. Goût moyennement fruité (raisins, cerises et notes de figues, traces de cerises sûres) avec des notes de crème (lactose) et de fumée de cigarette lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti aux notes terreuses et brûlées ainsi quun goût de caramel et quelques notes de mélasse puis en finale lon retrouve un léger-moyen goût de chocolat noir avec des notes dalcool doux, de houblon herbeux et terreux ainsi quun léger goût de noix. Post-goût long-moyen, légèrement amer de rôti (notes brûlées), de chocolat avec des notes dalcool, de houblon herbeux et de fruits (moût de raisins et de cerises).

Pours a very dark brown, almost black actually, with a good sized bubbly, beige head.  Aroma is malty and I guess more roasted.  There is a good amount of toffee, as well as nutty, dark licorice, and a little bit of chocolate.  It is a more unusual aroma actually.  I get a good deal of toffee and that licorice in the taste.  This has a surprisingly fruity or citrus tartness in here.  Kind of sweet as well.  Medium in body and smooth in texture.  Aftertaste is nutty toffee with that tartness mentioned above.  This is pretty good and a little different.  The more I sip, the more I seem to enjoy it.

Poured from an undated 16.9oz. bottle into a snifter. The beer is clear and a deep brown colo but looks essentially black in the glass.  The modest light brown head has about average retention and leaves some lacing on the glass. The rich, if not strong, aroma is mainly of dark (and lighter?) malts and some dark fruits, sweet and not smoky.  

T: The taste is nicely malty and rich, with plenty of dark fruit flavor (particularly plum, dried plum and date), some caramel and a hint of chocolate and spicy hops.  Some coffee and a faint hint of smoke in the finish.  Excellent sweet/bitter balance.  

M: Smooth with a medium carbonation that makes it lively and crisp for style.  Medium-to-heavy body.

O: Flavorful and goes down easily.  Has some qualities that overlap with a Baltic Porter, including a fairly well-hidden high ABV.  Readily recommended.
Bottle 0.5ltr: Very dark brown brew with an good taste of blue fruits, orange and choclate, this an wonderful Porter brew indeed.

Very dark brown almost black with some ruby tints and a thick, frothy, lasting, very lacy, beige head. Smells of molasses, strong malt with an overall roast, chocolate, coffee malt presence with some raisin, plum, liquorish. Seriously all the solid Stout elements in one lovely mix. Medium creamy body with soft carbonation. Sweet start with chocolate and caramel malt but with a rustic molasses, raisin and dark fruit elements it then moves to a bitter roast coffee middle that is earthy with some of the bitterness of dark chocolate. The finish is a lasting bitter and dusty yet smooth as silk. This is one solid porter. Dark Malty and delicious.

500ml bottle poured into chalice glass on Christmas day 2012. Mahogany black in colour with dark ruby highlights and a thick creamy tan head. Strong aroma of black treacle and warm yeasty dough lingers on the nose. Superb creamy mouthfeel and good lacing throughout. Dark malt complex gives a moist maltloaf base with strong sweet notes of old fashioned treacle toffee, bournville chocolate, black coffee and syrupy dates. There is a faint hop prickle which gives a dry earthy note mixed with tobacco smoke. Finish is so so smooth, malty with black molasses and pontefract cake very much in evidence. This is a cracking new! porter and thank you J.W. Lees for keeping the gravity high - bucking the current trend there. If you like your ales strong, dark and malty and you like what you read on the label, then your in for a treat - I can understand the high ratings.
Very dark brown colour. Aroma has some chocolate malts. Flavour is quite sweet with hints of chocolate. Overall has a very smooth and rich feel.

Bottle from Dom. Many thanks buddy. Manchester. So much to answer for. I think I know where to get hold of Ola Dubh 40 year for not too much. Sounds good to me. Better than a Fruet? OI! Wheres my 10% discount???

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 Bottled	24/12/12.  A black beer with an off-white head.  A chocolately light roast aroma.  Slick and smooth chocolatey flavours.  A bit of boozy.  Clean and tasty and very drinkable.  Score 3.7Subsequent ratings scored 3.5 and 3.6. Average becomes 3.6

UPDATED: APR 14, 2013 500ml bottle courtesy of mr_h. Very dark brown colour, not much head. Toasted plum aroma. Raisin & plum pudding flavour. Quite smooth. Ok but I think this is too highly rated on ratebeer.
500ml bottle from Sainsburys, Prestwick - clear very dark brown, creamy beige head, minimal lacing, aroma of sweet malty, plums, chocolate flavour, bit of fruit, clean dry finish

Interesting nose with some plummy notes and sweet malt and a bit of brussels sprouts.  Taste is vineous and dark with slight chocolatey notes but more bitter burnt molasses.  Its not heavy though, and carries the alcohol well into a long finish.

Bottle. Medium tan head. Dark brown to black body. Nose is candied red fruits, alcohol, hops, a little spice, black malt. Fairly bittersweet to taste, with some alcoholic burn. Tastes fairly thin for his strength. Bitter finish. Warming. Its all about the finish with this beer. Practically demands cheese and biscuits. Id agree with the style classification on this site of porter. Very drinkable, but a little unsophisticated for its strength.
Definitely more like a Baltic porter, the bitterness and dry finish are rather splendid. Definitely all down to the gravity. Definitely.

50cl bottle from Sainsburys. Magohany with a reddish glow and a  ring of beige head; rich aroma of molasses and treacle; soft and creamy with raisins and sweet malts; and a mix of red wine and milk chocolate to finish.
Bottle. Black and malty  with a powerful smooth flavour. Traces of chocolate linger making for a dangerously drinkable beer.

Overall a slightly impressive beer.  But definately pleasing with a rich mixture of flavors. Dries on the palate almost like a wine so the flavors are intense but fleeting. Mild carbonation, slight head clearing quickly with carbonation dissipating to a bitter reminder as it sits.  I find it presents flavor better when slightly warmer. All in all a very drinkable beer.

Bottle at home - 13/10/12 from Stevenage JS.
Pours mid black with a thin tan head that soon forms a pond and clears to the edge.
Roast malt nose, licqourice, dark fruit and a touch soapy.
Taste is dark fruits, figs, dates, plum, hint of spice, molasses.
Fuller end of medium bodied with a bit of bollocks. Soft carbonation leading to a dry fruity finish.
This beer improved as it warmed and the flavours developed a little more.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from Sainsburys. Dark brown pour with a light tan head. Vanilla, raisin, licorice, cocoa and chocolate aroma. Quite a nice nose I must say. Licorice, toffee, caramel and a little chocolate flavour. Tasty. Long, dry sweet finish. Throat warmer. Like this one.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Near black with a foamy, off-white head and plenty of carbonation. Sweet, slightly vinous aroma, with plenty of wood and fruit. Flavour was sweet, with chocolate and caramel notes, some roastiness and a dryish, fruity finish. excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 Bottle from Sainsburys Team Valley, Gateshead. A black beer with burnt currants, red fruit, port, ginger, liquorice and chocolate flavours followed by a warming, creamy plum finish. An excellent Old ale.  Also drank after ageing for 2 years - still excellent!

Bottle pours an almost raven black ale with a thick frothy tan coloured head. Aroma  of some roast malts dark chocolate and demerara sugar.  Taste is caramel, bitter chocolate, dark fruit cake and a bit of vanilla with a nice bitter finish, all in a smooth package. I though it great.

bottle    pours very  deep ruby brown  almost black with beige lingering head  . aroma is coffee , some toasted malt  , liquorice . taste is cofffee , toasted malt , cough medicine   .  carbonation is medium    mouthfeel starts full becoming more watery at finish    alcohol is amazingly well hidden  a decent dangerously drinkable brew

500ml bottle. Poured a deep, ruddy brown colour with a one-finger, mostly lasting beige head. Liquorice, roasted malt,  spicy & fruity malts. Fine on the nose, but the alcohol came through a fair bit more on the tongue. Medium body, soft to medium carbonation with a dryish, modestly lingering bittersweet finish. Fine with good malt characteristics but I just felt that the alcohol was too present, which spoiled the rest of the beer for me to a degree.

Bottle in Spainsburys beer-off. Very dark ruby appearing black with a subsiding cappuccino-hued foam. Unusual, herbal liqueur (Becherovka, Jagermeister) sweetness on the nose with suggestions of mint, plum and liquorice. Smooth and sweet (but not cloying) with dark bread, spiced apple, liquorice and more herbal touches. Bit of a silky-drinking, mildly lactic, dubbelish thing happening like a brown-sugared Westmalle stirred with a Swedish liquorice pipe. Proof that strong beer doesnt always have to punch you in the face with flavour, sweetness, alcohol or really anything much to entice you into drinking half a litre in 15mins.

bottle at home ... deep brown red ... thin tan head ... soft blackcurrant toffee malt nose ... over fizzy ... dark fruits ... blackcurrant and barest licorice ... soft malts ... light woody bitter linger

Bottle.  Poured black with a smallish tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, light smoke and licorice, touch of dark fruit.  Flavor is roasted malt, touches of coffee, smoke, licorice, nuts, a good bit of dark fruit.  Mild sweetness.  Finishes dry.

Bottle from Sainsburys, Pinner. A black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Dark fruit, coffee, malty aroma. Tastes similar, dark fruit, malty, some coffee and caramel, definite plum taste. Best beer Ive had from Sainsburys for a long while.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2015 The aroma outdoes the the flavour on this one. A chocolate/fruit combination that somehow manages to be a little bland. Not unpleasant by any means, and it possibly suffered slightly as I tried this immediately ater the Batemans Mocha.

500 ml bottle served cool. Black with a fading beige head. Plummy licquorice aroma, delicious dark fruit, licquorice shiraz and leather flavours. Slightly stick mouthfeel, delicious porter that is creeping towards being an Old Ale, but is none the worse for it.

500ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a large head.  Aroma is nuts, leather bound books and raisin and caramel malt.  Taste has old leather to start.  Smokey, leathery finish.  Blackberries on the aftertaste.

Bottle, from Sainsburys Hessle. Jet black, initially good fluffy beige head thining to a lasting surface sheen, low condition. Initial aromas of rye bread and smoked bacon followed by sweet liquorice and coffee. Soft and sweet in the mouth with a gentle liquorice note, hints of dandelion and burdock, and a low roast barley bitterness, alcohol is quite noticable. Pleasant lingering liquorice sweetness in the finish, some gentle roasted bitterness and retronasal alcohol.

Bottle.  Near black with a beige foam.  Aromas are earthy coffee with dark berries and chocolate.  Liquorice and marzipan with floral notes and a good deal of woody and nutty notes   Xmas pudding with some smokiness.  Flavours are sweet raisins and cola with roast coffee and spices.  Plummy and peppery with dark chocolate bitterness.  Earthy and dry on the finish with herbal aspects.  Very good.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2012 Bottle from Sainsburyâs Nairn Very dark brown, rich tan head that dissipates to creamy thin layer, good lacing Aroma - Rich dark malts, dark fruits, hint of treacle, molasses, fruit cake, hint of sherry Taste - Rich dark malts, smooth soft roast, dark fruits, soft treacle, touch of toffee malts, molasses, some chocolate, fruit cake spices, bit of belgian quad in there, complex, really smooth, alcohol pretty well hidden Palate - soft carb, medium to full body. Very smooth palate, fairly sweet fruity dark malts. Finish as main flavour, very very smooth, bit of warming alcohol, rich fruit cake, not as dry as mentioned. Overall - Well I didnât expect this for Â£1.50 from Sainsburyâs. Itâs really good - complex, lots going on and the alc is well hidden. Perhaps itâs a bit over smooth and the dark syrupy malts can get a little cloying - itâs crossing into old ale territory for me. Surprised by this one.

500ml bottle from Sainsburys.  Black beer, dark brown edges with thick beige head.  Actually quite a good baltic porter style beer.  Lots of milk chocolate.  Some decent maltiness.  Shame its filtered and pasteurised otherwise this could be a fantastic beer. Lots of plum fruit.  Really very good.

Coffee, pipe tobacco, malt, caramel, and some fruit in the aroma.  Flavor starts slightly sweet with some chocolate and fruit.  Chocolate/coffee bitterness and a little alcohol in the finish.  Really good.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas dark bread, toasted and mild coffee, light to moderate herbs and resin for the hops, light for earth for the yeast, with raisin, port and toffee in the background. Head is average size, frothy, tan with no lacing and is fully diminshing. Color is very dark brown with a red tint. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, watery but perhaps a litlle slick, with a soft carbonation  and a lightly to moderately alcoholic and lightly dry finish. Nice toasty aromas, well balanced flavors and a full mouth feel are the best aspects of this very English-style Porter.

Pours an inky black with a medium, light tan head that stays. Aroma is subtle, but inviting. Light on the palate, and surprisingly sweet for a porter.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I was a bit surprised by this beer.  It comes in a dark brown bottle and its an ale.  So I was expecting a copper color or brown.  This beer is dark... I mean really dark.  So I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.  It is a very nice dark beer with more of a porter taste than an ale.  Definitely worth a try.

Appearance: dark browns under a mousse-like tan head which slowly fades into a thin layer. Smoky embers along the bottom when held up to light. Swirls with random tan spots and a dense creamy head.

Nose: creamy. Chocolate Oreo cookies. Milky. Chocolate cake. Chocolate malt with a whisper of dark fruits mixed in  raisins and prunes. Pumpernickel bread.

Palate: creamy  like a chocolate cloud melting in my mouth with milky Oreo cream delights. Prunes and raisins covered in chocolate brownies. Chocolate malt. Faint tingle of black fruit tartness along the edges  plum skins. Glides across tastebuds like silk. Milk chocolate in the breath.

Final Thoughts: yum!! Truly a delight of all the senses, from sight to smell to sound to mouthfeel to taste to finish. Another winner from the fine folks at J. W. Lees in Middleton, England. As with all English imports and otherwise, drink as fresh as possible. This is not a beer you want to age so savor now and by more later.

(500 ml from McKean and Charles) Dark brown with three and a half fingers of tan head that recede a bit but leave a lasting cap. Nose of chocolate and caramel. Mouthfeel smooth but a bit loose and thin (which I understand to be acceptable for the style). Outstanding malty flavor of chocolate, caramel, honey and a bit of smoke. Medium-light bitter pinch in finish. ABV very well-hidden. Excellent, I could drink gobs of this stuff.
Poured a almost black color with a tan head from a bottle.  Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate and a twinge of nuts.  Flavor is the same, nice porter overall.

Bottle, 500ml from Patrick, cheers. Black with ruby hue, cream head. Sweet start, but this fades into a fruity, blackberry, blueberry then chocolatey mix, becoming quite full on the palate. Wine like hints, full Bordeaux, maybe there is some syrupy notes towards the end. Why this is so hard to get hold of here I dont know. Decent.
Bottle. Pours near black with a beige head. Lightly roasted malty aroma with some nutty sweetness. The flavor has dry roasted malts, some lightly sweet nutty notes, and a dry finish. Pretty good.

Aroma of milk chocolate, raisins, brown sugar and brandy. Appearance was black with bubbly tan head. Flavor matched the nose, with the addition of some coffee and nuts; virtually no hop presence. Palate was bubbly and the mouthfeel was medium. Good; based on the description, I may have had an old bottle. With that being said, I would go out of my way for this, but it was a very well made porter.

In aroma, its fruity and has a complex malt profile with a hint of alcohol, almost like a barley wine.  The flavor is heavily malty and fruity, a bit of dark fruit and possibly cherry in there.  Excellent ale, among the best.

In short: A creamy porter curiously blending nuttiness and 
How: Bottle 500ml.  Consumed probably fresh, a few weeks after purchase
The look: Near black body with a medium tan head with medium retention
In long: Nose is a bit roasted, some crusty raisin pie.  Taste has a nuttiness reminiscent of cashews, fresh dates and prunes, dark breakfast grape juice, milk chocolate bar, pie crust, raisins, some caramel.  Mild leafy hops presence that adds a fresh tobacco leafs flavor to the beer but not much bitterness.  Mouthfeek is creamy and fluffy with a carbonation that has a lot of very soft bubbles.  My description seems to indicate a good beer but the truth is that I thought the fruitiness and nuttiness didnt work well together at all, like someone had poured a glass of breakfast dark grape fruit juicy in my a perfectly fine porter.  This seems to be a beloved beer from a flagship English brewery so I apologize to any Englishman for my bad review of this loved and I also apologize in advance for this tyop.

Smells yumbo, looks very intensely dark red (in a blue glass!), amazingly bitter/sweet/smoky all at once.  Is it thinner than the average porter?  Really good beer - makes me wish I lived back then, but then I wouldnt have any internet : )

Bottle. Deep brown, approaching black body. Tan head, frothy, slowly diminishing. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, sweet licorice, tobacco. Hint of dark fruit. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture turning creamy/slick in the finish, moderate carbonation. A malty beer with thick caramel, chocolate and fruit flavors. Some earthiness, leather. A bit sweet, but good stuff overall.
On tap. Black pour with tan head and lace. Dark molasses and light coffee aroma. Coffee, creamultion, burnt molasses, with a good earthy hops bitter. Medium full bodied and smooth.

Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, caramel, & dark fruit. Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit, and licorice; Nicely balanced; Overall, very good porter.
Weak fig aroma. Garnet brown, medium tan head. Fig dominated flavor. There is a little heat on the palate. Balanced, little complexity, even less hop flavor.
On tap at Magnolia Brewery. Pours dark brown with a modest tan head and a coffee aroma. There is a tasty coffee and treacle flavor with a dry sour tinge at the finish. A nice porter.

The aroma is brown sugar, wood, chocolate, coffee.  The flavor is slightly cedar, sweet, brown sugar, coffee.  The appearance is dark brown, light tan head.  The finish is piney hops.  The body is medium, maybe a tad thin.  Decent overall.
Cask at Redlight. Reddish brown pour, little carbonation. Tart, roasted grain aroma. Roasted grain, caramel malt and a very smooth body. Nice session porter.
Pours a dark brown with a thick white head. Aroma is sour dark fruits. Taste is roasted malts, bananas and sour candy. Palate is weak. Overall a decent beer

On cask @ redlight redlight.  Roased malts on the nose with hints of chocolate and yeast.  Pours very dark brown with a solid white head.  Sweet with dark fruits upfront, vinous, with dark raspberry and plum, very light on the palate with tobacco and hints of licorice in the finish.  Very interesting!

Pint on cask at Dilly Deli, Dark chestnut with dark mocha foamy head, sour aroma with light caramel malt, flavor is huge sour malt up front with spicy tannins on finish, complex, the spiciness is slightly overpowering on finish, tough finishung the pint
Draft at Churchkey.  Almost completely black.  Aroma of coffee grounds.  Taste is prunes, raisins, dark roasted malts.  Tasty.

In the bottle. Pours black with a large beige head. Big sherry or port aroma. Molasses and caramel as well. Nuts molasses caramel and a wine-like flavor. While the body is full, this could stand to be a bit more chewy.

Bottle.  Pours black with a large, frothy, tan head, mostly lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, molasses, roasted grain), average hops (herbs), average yeast (earth) with notes of smoke and peat.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation.  Long duration, light sweetness and acidity, moderate bitterness.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2017 Quite rich, complex and fruity.  Much maltier and less roasted that I expected at first.  I pronounce it yummy.  Serving: Bottle
Bottle Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is licorice, alcohol, spices, ocoa. Flavour is roasted, malt, licorice, alcohol, spices, cocoa, dried fruits. Full bodied nice beer.

Bottle. Its a clear, very dark brown beer, a beige finger-thick head sits on top. The aroma is really delicious, with cocoa, some licorice, notes of alcohol, and roasted malts. Full-bodied and warming, with flavors of roasted malts, dried fruits, cocoa and some licorice. Roasted, warming finish. A really pleasant and tasteful beer, the aroma even slightly more lovely. 091127
Bottle. Black colour with large creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of licorice. Sweet spicy flavor. Creamy palate.

The bottle doesnt specify that this is a Porter, but the subsequent experience points right in that direction, from chocolaty aroma to more than a typical light English-ale palate.  This palate here is rich and chewy with some quasi-Baltic-Porter rich chocolate flavor that doesnt overpower despite the richness.  A very satisfying drink all-around.
Everything I like in a beer.  Dark body, hearty aroma, creamy head that lasts, and the typically complex flavors I love in English brews .  I will be getting more of this.
Red-brown pour with a brown head. Hop aroma and rasted malt, faint dark fruits, and a little sweetness. Sweet malt taste, smooth, creamy. It had a nice aftertaste.
Poured dark reddish brown/black, chocolate, dark fruits, roasted malts, little molasses, slight licorice.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, plums, nuts, licorice and notes of chocolate.

Pours black with off-whit generous head.  Licorice and malty aroma.  Above average mouthfeel.  Good representation of English porter, most drinkable black licorice mostly, some chocolate malts. Not very sweet.

Black in color. Smells like light malt. Smooth understated delicate nose for a porter. Roast comes out more as the beer warms up. Good typical porter. Dont love it, but theres nothing to really dislike either.

Rich rum raisin smell ~ beautiful lively tan bubbly head. Taste is realyl delicious, with plum accents, chocolate cherry tones, and a slight sherry burn. This carries a hearty malty backbone that holds it all together nicely. An exceptional beer with an amazing focus on balance.
Pours a dark brown body and tan head.  Aromas and flavors of maple, smoke and malt.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a longlasting tan head. Has a roasted malty bready alcoholic aroma with hints of chocolate. Has a fruity malty slightly roasted chocolate flavor with some hints of licorice. Hasa fruity malty chocolate finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Bottled.  Poured deep brown with a creamy tan head capped by an interesting array of looser bubbles.  The aroma opened with rich and succulent molasses with sweeter chocolates, vanilla, and bready notes laced throughout.. just a little prickly warmth on the back.  The flavor was also led by molasses, picking up dry smoke, tobacco, and a touch of licorice.. sweeter chocolates on the back-end with a little vinous character.. a little sweeter than expected, but tasty.  Medium-bodied and dry on the palate.. scratchy feel especially across the middle.. felt alright, and there was some tasty, intriguing stuff in here.
Pours a dark copper brown with a one finger tan head. The nose is coppery, acetaldehyde, caramel, malty, some peat. THe flavor is malty, peaty, caramel, sweet, English feel.

Bottled. An opaque brown beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of sweet malt and tobacco as well as lighter notes of roasted malt, alcohol, and over ripe fruits. The flavor is sweet with notes of over ripe fruits, alcohol, and roasted malt, as well as lighter notes licorice, leading to a lightly bitter finish.
Black pour with a small off white head. Aroma holds cream, chocolate, roasted barley. Flavor is excellent, lots of coffee and chocolate- very thick and rich. Very nice porter.

dark brown pour dissipating head.  tobacco, Tabasco, dark chocolate, prune.  really nice flavor, tobacco comes out, sweet and dark.  As it warms the flavors become more pronounced.  some really nice roast going one in the finish.  good shit.

Black pour with small light tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted barley, dark fruit, and the most mild hint of citrus and vanilla. Flavor is loaded with rich chocolate, roasty coffee, a definite tobacco aspect, and cream. Palate is super thick and silky. Roasty, dry finish. Excellent

Bottle.  Pours a very dark reddish brown, too dark to see thru, with a small fizzy khaki head.  Aroma of some roast and fruity english yeast, malty with woody vinous notes.  Wonderful flavor, deep and interesting, fruity, spicy, distant roast, full and oily, chewy plums, candied tobacco, chocolate pudding, some woody tannins towards the finish.  Long dry bitter dried dark fruit raisin aftertaste.  
This beer seems to hit my sweet spot... an oily roasty vinous sweet old ale.  Full bodied with a full oily mouthful with soft large bubbly carbonation, not sticky just slightly syrupy.

Bottled (thanks to the craziest bartender ever!). Very dark brown colour, close to black, mediumsized fluffy beige head. Some lace. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee some wet smoked wood and also liquorice and mild notes of raisins. Flavour is roasted malts, some toffee, mild chocolate and coffee as well as some slight fruity notes. Very well balanced and hides the alcohol completely.

mmm mmm good! bottle from Knightly Spirits in Orlando.  Pours a very dark brown with a big beige head.  chocolate, roast, prunes, molasses and maybe a touch of smoke.  Flavor folows suit with a great mouthfeel and loads of toffee, malt, light chocolate, and some molasses.  Quality beer.  Very nice.  Borat likes.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a massive tan head.  Aromas are chocolatey with a bit of a plum.  Flavor is big darkness with fruit and cocoa.  A little weak & thin.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Poured to a deep black-brown with a tan head that immediately shrank to nothing and left no head or lacing. Aroma was a sweet, chocolate-toffee-malt and the mouthfeel was thick and syrupy. Taste was more of the malt chocolate, infused with some licorice and a hint of smoky wood. Finish was thick and unpleasant.

Not a fan of this one.

From bottle. Bitter aroma hits first then settles to a port or whisky like aroma with liquorice, brown sugar and berries. Extremely deep ruby to liquefied liquorice colour. Thin lace. Smooth ale, strong liquorice flavour. Rich with a smooth texture. Warming ale, full bodied like a good chocolate cake. Nice.

The smell is roasty, chocolate, malts, coffee, and little sweetness.  The look is dark, black in color, and has a nice tan colored head.  The taste is roasty, chocolate, malts, and some coffee.  Decent porter.

great aroma of soy, roasted malt, sweet malts, chocolate, and some bourbon.
Flavor is super rich, lots of chocolate, sweet, and roasted malt, and more of the burnt soy, with a touch of a bourbon barrell flavor. this is quite a robust porter, a wicked beer, reminds me of a classic english porter.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits. Pours a pitch black color, an inviting 1.5 inch tan head, and tight, sifting curtains of lace. The nose is rye, subtle soy sauce, apple, and bread. Flavors are similar with chocolate and smoky, woodsy flavors all around, front-to-back. High carbonation and medium/full body. Very good; a delicious porter.
Dark brown in color with a good sized tan head. Aroma is of caramel, chocolate and sweet malt. Taste is of malt and bitter chocolate

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2009 Pours mahogany into an English pint.  Mocha head with excellent retention. Twangy fruit aromas. Creamy with cocoa and pit fruit from front to back.  Lasting chalky licorice finish.
Black with a big and lasting light brown head. Chocolate and prunes and caramel aroma. Sweetish chocolate flavour with notes of dried fruits

Bottle. Dark brown almost black body with a creamy beige head that lasts. Roasted malts, chocolate dark fruits, tobacco and a some alcohol in aroma. Creamy body. Pretty roasty aroma with chocolate, 	
liquorice and a good bitterness.

This may be my new favorite, when I can afford it!  Pours a dark black with a light head that disipated too quickly.  Aroma of fresh malt and roast coffee fill your nose. You get the coofee, the chocolate and malt, along with some raisin.  The mouthfeel is full and velvety.   Even my inexperienced 21 year old daughter could tell this was an exceptional beer (what does she know?  More than I thought!)  The mild bitterness and dry finish make this a most enjoyable pint!  Worth moving to Manchester just to ahve a pint on a regular basis!
A bottle tasted at Pikkulintu. Thanks Markku. Pale Brown hewad. Dark reddish brown colour. Sweet malty fully taste with hints of raisins. Slight coffee aromas. Mild hoppiness. Fine beer.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2008-11-29) Black. Small tan coloured head. Raisin and sweetness in nose. Raisin, liquorice, bitterness, roastedness and sweetness in taste. Raisin and light bitterness in aftertaste. FIne beer.

500ml bottle - - Pikkulintu, Helsinki.
Bottle 1, end of bottle, warm and flat - Huge sweet raisiny and slightly marmitey aroma. Very full and complex palate. Massive oaky wood component, but moist tobacco and some flowery hops are subtly in there too. Very rich and woody. Stunning english porter. 
Bottle 2, same night - Malt loaf in aroma, way woodier taste, some butter too. Softer but thinner palate.

50cl bottle @ VinensVerden, Odense.Pours black with a small creamy brown head. Nose is roasted, liquorice & chocolate.Smooth wih a pleasant bitter roast & some dark fruits.. A very well made "strong" British porter! Nice!

Bottle 50cl.Clear dark black color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, roasted, caramel, coffee, dusty, light to moderate dark berry, raisin, plum, alcohol. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, and dusty finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to lively, finish feel is light alcoholic. (010908)

500ml Bottle: Aroma of roasted malts, light chocolate, slight caramel, and some earthiness.  Poured dark brown in color with a medium-sized, dense, creamy, dark tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Decent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of roasted malts, chocolate, cream, caramel, dark ripe fruits, slight tobacco, slight burnt malts, slight piney hops, sugar-cone, and a bit of nuttiness.  Medium to full body.  Thick, creamy, smooth texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Bitter-sweet chocolate, roasted malt, creamy finish is lightly dry and delicious.

Pours pitch black, oily with a tall khaki head. Big heavy body, thick pour, but smooth and creamy. This beer seems to weigh a ton, dense bakers chocolate, black licorice, almost meaty flavor. This beer is delicious, but so heavy it takes away my drive to do anything productive, great beer for sitting around on a cold winter night reading a book.

Bottle from Belmont Station in Portland, OR--Poured a rich dark mostly black, slightly brown thick rich body with a creamy off-white head.  Nose of rich thick malt, chocolate, toffee, and dark fruity yeastiness.  Great roasted character.  Hints of vanilla, liquorish, rasins, and the sweetness of a Baltic Porter balanced by chalky deep cacao.  Excellent beer!

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of joergen. Pours a clear dark brown with a reddish glow and a tall, dense and lacing beige head. Sweetish hard roasted malt. Medium body with sweet hard roasted malts, some vanilla accents and a discreet malt bitter finish. Decent alright. 310808

EBF2008. It’s pitch black with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. The flavour has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, licorice, chocolate, raisin, plum and syrup. It’s a pleasant, smooth and nice baltic porter.

My drink no.13 at European Beer Festival, Copenhagen 08. This one was provided by the Danish Beerhouse stand/bar. Mahogany appearance with a tiny, beige head. Caramelised malty aroma. Rich in taste with decent amounts of chocolate, nuts and plums. Bittersweet ending. Quite dry, almost woody, in the mouth (12.09.2008).
Bottle at a Housewarming. Black - big brown lasting head. Burned, berries, vinous, licorice, nutty, chocolate. Nice power.

Bottle, bought @ Vinens Verden, Odense.
Deep brown with an impressive, creamy, light-beige head. Stunning duration with a steady creamy top. Mild, smooth aroma, good chocolate, some light nuttiness and light coffee. Medium carbonation, fine mouthfeel. Flavour is nice and sweet, good milky chocolate and hazel nuts. A long, liquorice, lingering finish.
Sweet aroma. Black color with a small off white head. Sweet smooth chocolate body with a thin chocolate palate. Not bad.

Poured from a 500ml bottle and served in an English pint glass.  This porter poured a slick black with a few mahogany highlights and a thin, lasting tan head.  Not much lace.  The aroma of the beer was made up of chocolate, caramelized sugar, plums, and licorice.  The flavor included baker’s chocolate, burnt sugar, dried citrus, and plums.  A lasting note of pipe tobacco was present at the finish.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with light carbonation.  Surprisingly, this shared some similar sugary dark fruit flavors found in their Harvest Ale barley wine.  Different, but pretty tasty.
Draught at EBF 2008. Dark copper, small head. Dark fruits, plums, chocolate, and some roasted coffee in the aroma. Medium bodied and smooth. Well balanced.

Bottle: Pours a deep brown with a ruby hue in the light and a tan dense film of head. The aroma is sweet with chocolate syrup, vanilla, mild roast, honey glazed nuts, sherry and plummy notes. Nice silky texture. The flavor is sweet. Has lots of sweet chocolate syrup upfront along with vanilla and sherry-like richness. The palate remains light and slick, despite it’s sweetness. Mild fruity notes of sweet raisin and plum, along with honey, which is followed by a nice, roasted crystal malt character giving it a pleasant nuttiness. Although it’s sweet, the palate is well textured, and it remains balanced and highly drinkable. Pretty good.

Botella. Black with a huge well lasting light brown creamish and bubbly head. Pleasant soft roasted maltiness, chocolate and coffee in the aroma. Quite good a mouthfeel. The flavour has roasted malt with dark fruits and chocolate along with bitter hops, some alcohol and smoke. Bit dry roasty chocolate smoked finish. A tasty brew indeed.
Black with huge beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, mild coffee and chocolate notes. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel and chocolate notes. Ends sweet with warming alcohol.
Amazing.  Notes of fig, coffee, chocolate, roasty, vanilla, molasis, raisin, and pipe tobacco. Creamy body.  Can’t wait to have this again.  Though, it is a bit pricey.
Black colour with a beige head. Light roasted aroma with dark fruit notes. Light roasted, coffee bitter flavor with dark fruit notes and hints of some sweetness.

Pours a grainy dark brown with a slight tan head.  Malty, molasses, raisin aroma.  Similar in taste, with light grains/nut and sweet chocolate.  Subtle carbonation.  Some tobacco like qualities in the finish.  Pretty drinkable, mellowed and balanced out more as it warmed.  Not bad, but too much sweet malt and not enough roast for me.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 50 cL bottle. Pours hazy brown to black with a creamy and tan head. Dark fruity and mild spiced aroma with a light fruity note. Light liqourice and smooth flavoured towards light dry and mild spiced. Lingering roasted and mild chocolate smooth finish. Nice one.

Bottle.
Black coloured with a medium sized beige ehad.
Light roasted aroma of coffee, hops, dish washer and hay.
Light roasted flavour of liquorice, fruits and dried fruits with notes of chocolate and coffee.
Light roasted finish.
Bland porter. Overrated.

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting light brown head. Hazy very dark almost black body. Alcohol dominated aroma of coffee and caramel. Heavily carbonated but relatively coffee flavor with a good deal of hops bitterness and alcohol. Long aftertaste.

black body, thin ring of tan bubbles.  aroma of sour fruit, plums, raisins, not a very good sign....  flavor is choclatey, plummy with a hint of hops. medium bodied with a slightly sweet finish.  an interesting brewwhich hides its alcohol well, but ultimately finishes a touch too sweet for me.

Taste 7/8. Black body with no head. Aroma: Roast, chocolate, mild nut and oil. Taste: Smooth roast, spicy hop, Choc., plum and nut. Mild cream start and then smooth dry middle with a nice lingering finish. The cavendish tobacco becomes  apparent in the back of the throat at the finish. Alcohol is well disguised. Nice brew.

bottle by way of pforei... pours a dark brown mahogany color with a thin vigorously carbonated tan head which dissipates quickly to nothing. lots of aromas... chocolate, roasty grain/maltiness,  prunes, goji berries, molasses sweetness and grass. just slightly sweet on the palate... flavors of coffee, vanilla beans, toasted nuts, prunes, star anise, molasses and wood. dry lightly tart and sour finish. coffee  in the aftertaste big time!...medium body with some prickly carbonation until it warms and begins to go flat. then, it gets slick. this is rather like a very refined baltic porter...

Draught @ Novare Res.  Black thick and viscous.  Admittedly I was off my trolley by the time i tried it.  According to my girlfriend you may loose your ability to use keys if you do not respect this brew.  I remember malt and foam.

on tap.. black pour,dense tan head good lacing.aroma of chocolate,molasses and dark fruit.flavor is complex mix of roasted malt,chocolate,annis,dark fruit and coffee.thick ,slick medium bodied and smooth .excellent

Draught @ Beer Table. Pours dark black with a dense tan head. Aroma is roasty malt, coffee with some dark fruit. taste is interesting -- dark, roasted malt up front, almost sweet with coffee and cocoa both showing up, that moves to dark fruit with a faint note of hoppy citrus and licorice on moderately dry finish. Palate is thick and oily, but with a moderately crisp carbonation. Quite a complex take on the style, well done, drinkable beer, though not one to pound all night in my opinion.
(pint bottle) deep oily black with almost no head. Roast malt aroma. Flavor is roast malt some chocolate and dark fruits. Alcohol undertone.

Dark black pour with a milk chocolate tan head.  Nose is dark roasted malt.  Light and creamy and more akin to a stout than a porter in my opinion.  Nice clean roasted malt taste with a chocolate highlight.  Finishes heavy and sits on your tongue.  A nice beer.

Thin head of fine and dense bubbles.  Sweet malty aroma with some leather, figs, prunes and other dark dried fruit.  Strange aroma but pleasing.  Color is a very dark brownish black.  Sweet malty flavor with lots of prunes again, anise and some molasses.  This is a very flavorful and fullfilling brew.  Much more than expected.  Although I can see many peeps who are not into stronger brews actually hating this beer.  Licorice stands out to me.  Finishes slick and oily with a thick aftertaste of licorice again.  A full bodied and delicious brew.  Much better than expected.
Dark wheat bread maltiness, some sweet dark fruits, and a little bit of dark chocolate and a hint of smokiness.  Loads of caramel malt, pretty well balanced, but overall pretty tame to me.

0.5L bottle pours deep darkness with nice looking mocha head. The aroma is at first roasty with a mix of malt balls, roasted malts, a dash of chocolate and then a load of sweet dark fruity esters. The taste is as dark fruit heavy as the nose with sweet Concord grape preserves, huckleberries and sugar coated black currents. A note of sweet molasses adds to the experience along with mild amounts of roasted malts, chocolate malts and black licorice.

500ml bottle.  Aroma of chocolate and dark fruits, with lighter notes of raisin, chestnut and molasses sweetness.  Dark black in color with a fine, slight head.  Flavor profile features a strong amount of dark, sugary malt sweetness to start, blended with hints of date, red grape, semi-sweet chocolate and a faint touch of earthy hop at the finish, which is long and shows hints of licorice and tobacco late.  Exceedingly light and smooth on the palate, leaving a lightly syrupy feel behind and with a medium-full body.  Rather pleasant overall.

Pours near black with a tick head. Aroma of chocolate and molasses.  Taste of chocolate with smoke.  Sweet, smooth finish into a slight bitterness.  Light mouthfeel.  Very drinkable and interesting beer.
2/23/08, bottle sample, 2005 vintage. pours dark brown with tan head. nose is ashy, some dark fruits, and chocolate. flavor is much of the same. pretty watery. decent but age hasnt helped probably.

Heavenly roast coffee aroma, dark chocolate too, ebony, pours a  small cappuccino head. Taste begins with liquorice, strong coffee, dark chocolate, its like a chocolate pudding or cake! Full bodied, richly bitter, beautifully balanced. Fabulous! Thanks Radek.

Dark brown pour.Tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. Tasted of chocolate , toffee, and hints of tobacco with a somewhat roasty finish. Mouth feel was on the thin side for claims "like a Baltic porter" Decent enough brew but pricey at $7 500ml.Worth a shot.

Tha Dan Journal #149.  Tasted 1/14/08.  500ml bottle.  Dark and opaque.  Fudgy fruity candy sugar aromas.  Medium bodied and slick.  Smooth malts with a bitter coffee finish.  Off-dry and bitter.  Touch mild effervescence.  Good toasty note.  Good long and sticky finish, but with a lingering acidity.  Quality!

Pour is a black with a tan head.  Light chocolate aroma with some molasses and pepper.  Flavor is deffinalty tobacco and some molasses.  Finish is creamy and thick.  Just above par for a porter and would probably be great with a cigar as it would bring out more of the tobacco quality.
Bottle. Dark toffee colored beer with a tan head. Light toffee aroma. Toffee, caramel, earthy flavor with backing hops. Medium body. Toffee lingers. Nice. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2008 Pours black with a beautiful tan head.  The nose is malt and licorice and dried fruit, especially plum.  Taste is licorice and dark chocolate with slight smokiness at the end.  Finishes fairly clean with just a slight bitterness.  Nice beer.

Smooth roasted malt aroma with chocolate notes. Essentially black in color with ruby hilites at the edges. The tan head never really arrived, just came flat and ringed. Full bodied with mild smooth carbonation. Flavor is roasted malt, dry, with varying fruits. Something of tobacco is arguable. Chocolate goes back and forth. Finish is a very nice, smooth clean sensation. Not really bitter at all. Drinks a bit like a port, but the flavor and alcohol arent similar. More baltic porters should move this direction. Its really a good drink.
Sweet, lightly roasted aroma.  Flavor has almost an Earl Grey tea character to it.  Super drinkable.
Not bad but not a favorite. Lighter for a so called Porter. Slightly dry on the finish.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Black, with a nice foamy tan head that disappears quickly. Smells like prune or rasin and a bit of coffee. Flavor is also rather fruity - prune and raisin again, and touches of coffee and cocoa. Finish is sort of a dry red wine or something like that.

Pours a dark, opaque black with a smallish brown head.  Light, fruity aroma with some toastiness, caramel and just the slightest hint of molasses.  More fruity and light than some porters which is not at all bad.  A very pleasing beverage.

Had this while hanging out with Wendy and some friends in Springfield last night.  Nose of dried fruit & flowers, some berries & alcohol, toffee & caramel.  Pours black with garnet highlights.  The average lasting creamy beige head leaves light lace.  The front is roasted but sweet, the middle is warm complimented with moderate acidity, the finish is roasted chocolate & caramel with hint of anise.  The medium to full creamy body is soft and the finish feels dry.
Quite a nice rich beer, with some great character. Its got a nice smooth body with a creamy feel to the rest. slight toasted and a little fruity. Great flavors.
This aroma is chocolaty, toasty, and nutty. The appearance is dark brown with a small tan head. The flavor is like the aroma and bitter. The palate is thin. Overall its pretty good but not great.

From the 500ml bottle, the beer pours an opaque brown, the head modest and creamy tan, as it evaporates, the lacing provides a concealing curtain to drape the glass. Nose has a sweet malt aroma, molasses, caramel, and a touch of earthiness, with the roasted grain present. Start is rich in sweet malt, a bit of bitterness at the back; touch of bitterness, top is rich and full in feel to the palate. Finish has a benignant acidity, the hops understated but noticeable, quite dry and sweet until the end.

This definately stood out against the other three standard porters tried on the night and stood up well against the two Baltic porters.
