Pours nearly black with good sized off white head that left nice lace. The Aroma had hints of port, toffee and was acompanied with lots of burnt malt smells. The taste had good balance between sweet and bitterness. The aftertaste lasted quite a long while and the body was nice and creamy. One of the best porters I have had. I need to try it head to head with Fullers and Nogne.

16.9oz bottle-pours a light brown head with bubbles and dark brown color.  Aroma is caramel/toffee/molasses-dark/medium malt, some earthy.  Taste is caramel/toffee/molasses/dark fruit/licorice-dark/medium malt, some earthy/bitter hops.  Medium/full body.  Good cold weather beer.  OK carbonation.  Thanks jwc215 for sharing.

The owner of Aldgate pulled this bottle out and shared it with the few of us at his pub that night.  Black with deep tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts, plums, raisins, caramel, and some sherry.  Full, smooth body.  Flavor is similar to the aroma with the dark fruits really showing through.  Roasted caramel malts, tobacco.  I couldnt get enough of this brew.
10/29/2007: Bottle. Opaque black body with a deep almond colored head.  Strong aroma of alcohol and fruit.  Rich fruit flavors (raisin, plum) in addition to alcohol, chocolate malt and candy sugar.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown color with a frothy mocha head.  Incredible aroma of roasted malts, raisins and plums, must and tobacco.  Smokey, roasted malt flavor.  Dark fruits and a bit musty.  Somewhat thin for the big flavors.  Nice.

On tap at town hall.
Dark pour w/ a whispy head and light lace.  Aroma of light grapes and plums some carmels and a touch of syrup.  Avg pal.  Flavor is oddly sweet w/ a touch of tart.. some light raisen and plum a lightly dry finish w/ some chocolates.. no signs of the fairly high alcohol, light tobacco flavors come through as it warms.  Great complexity.

Bottle. Dark brown with a sparkling rubyish tinge and a creamy brown head. Aroma is slightly papery but otherwise pleasant with notes of sweet chocolate, roast, and toffee. Thick viscous body - lots of chocolate with some bitter coffee lingering in the background. 
Some alcohol warmth.

Bottle 500 ml
Appearance :Quiet deep darkness, mostly black with only small ray of brown. White crown. Classic white on black. Nose : Dry brown malt with good notes of port , roasted dry beans. Clean stout like roast .7+
Flavour/Palate : Smooth and clean with dark roasted malt. Clean, warming alcohol. Lighter in character, gently brewed. Semi-sipper that at such strength might be dangerous.

Black/dark brown topped by a small, dense, cream colored head. Aroma and flavor of roasty, bittersweet chocolate, rich burnt caramel, subtle smoke, dried dark fruits, earthy tobacco, and hints of gamey meat. Medium/full body, smooth. Unique brew. Very good.
Bottle. Dark brown body, minimal head, sweet nose. Very sweet, malty, with Lees house character, portish, cloying, no hop character to speak of.

Wow. I was wondering what the style was when i was drinking it. I had a bottle of this laying in my fridge for a about a year. Popped the top, and got something that, honest to god, reminded me of Thomas Hardy Ale. I wasnt guessing this was a porter given the thin body to it. Definitely malty and sugary, but in a good, mellow way. Virtually no head when poured from my bottle, but fizzy like a soda in sound. I think the "bitterness" described in other posts is where they get the chocolate. However, mine, which had been sitting cold for several monhts, developed quite a kick, definitely a alcohol flavor as an after taste. (Bottle Pour 9/12/10027)

Mode: Bottle

dark brown, thin tan head, rich sweet malt aroma, good body, rich malt flavor, big sweetness, nice dark malt character, touch of chocolate,

17 oz bottle  via August 2007 Secret Santa (thanks!). Pours a near black with a large tan head. Nose is chocolate, almonds, and fruity esters. Taste is chocolate, plums, nuts, earthy hops, roasted grains. Body is medium, carbonation just right. This is not bad at all, and sort of seems like a baltic porter except with ale yeast.

Pours midnight brown w/ a medium sized, creamy spattered froth. Good hangtime w/ a full yet thin ring and canopy lace. Aromas are a bit rustic of sweet chocolate malts and molases. Full nectar w/ relaxed residual effers creating a slighty creamy texture. Moderately roasted w/ a big malty sweetness that takes control leaving remnants of cocoa, molases, cakebread, and coffee bean to be accounted for. This brew is very wet on the palate. The aroma and flavors have a defined old world flare. The finish is bittered nicely yielding a lingering roasted cocoa sweetness. Overall: Baltic in nature yet well balanced and not too rich. I could actually drink a couple of these over the course of an evening.

500ml bottle in pint glass.  Pours black with tan head and lasting ring.  Earthy smoky aroma.  Fruity, raisiny, smokey flavor with chocolaty port finish.  Very smooth.  Medium-full bodied and low carbonation.  Very drinkable. Very nice.

Mostly likely 04 vintage, but Im not sure. Pours very dark brown with a small tan head. Strong aromas of raisins and prunes, as well as some tobacco, and molasses. Roasted and semi-sweet flavors of juicy prune, raisin, a bit of a chocolate undertone, a bit of molasses, and a slightly earthy vinous note towards the finish. Palate is medium, with a velvety mouth - feel, and some lingering dark fruit.
Black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is roasty with coffee, and light caramel.  taste is pretty malty, light roastiness, with some alcohol showing and red grapes.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2009 0.5 L. Opaque black, with a large and lasting creamy cap. Aromas of spicy prunes, molasses, chocolate raisins and a hint of smoke. Tastes of earthy molasses; raisins sauteed in brown sugar and sesame soy; slight chicory and grassy herbs, some gunmetal and marshmallow. Smooooth and medium-heavy bodied, with some slight tingle on the end. Excellent porter.

Yummy beer! Good head and nice lace. Opaque. Commercial description seems to be right on. Velvety texture. Aroma is very pronounced rich and fetid. Great finish. Drinkable. Had this one at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, WI USA.

pint bottle - very dark ruby red color with smallish quickly dissapearing light tan head. Aroma is nutty and vinous, with significant notes of red grapes, dates, burnt caramel, dust, soil, wet stone, sour cherries, blackberry, charred oak and vanilla. Flavor has chewy malts, fair amount of toasted caramel and oak, faint touch of honey. Finish is mildly sweet. I liked this a lot, the aroma is a bit musty, which makes it fall short of truly stellar, but stil very nice.
Not a strong aroma, some raisins.  Black body with a thin head.  Full palate.  Lightly sweet raisins in the taste, with some roasted malt.  Good porter.

from a 500 ml bottle.  pours very dark with dark tan head.  sweet malty flavor (similar to brazilian black beers) with dark fruit flavors reminiscent of macerated dried fruit marinated in red wine.  coffee and tobacco flavors are there too.  i didnt sense the dry long wine-like finish.  the avb wasnt that apparent to me.  if you like your porter malty sweet with mouth feel, then this is for you.  a bit dear at $5.99/500ml.

Bottle:  The aroma is a combination of chocolate, sour plums, and yeast.  Pours a dark brown with some orange hilights along the edges of the glass.  The head is beige, but really struggles to have any sort of staying power outside of a thin ring.  The flavor starts with lots of chocolate that lasts from start to finish.  The moderate sourness in the nose is almost non-existent, but there is a strong fruity backbone.  It finishes with light coffee notes and a touch of acidity.
Dark brown with lite head.  Blackberry and roast aroma notes.  Mild blackberry, sweet malts, mild roasted hops flavour.  Smooth entry with mild bitter finish.

Pours coal black.No light peeking thru this beer.Not too much aroma here.A slight sweetness of fruit.Flavor is coffee, caramel, and chocolate.the finish has some fruit wine likeness with a slight metallic end.

Bottle:  Very dry aroma, smoky/tobacco-like, and slightly medicinal and tart, a very strong aroma.  Boring head with little retention.  In the mouth, mild vanilla like sweetness, understated by mild caramel notes starts this beer.  The vanilla flavors become more pronounced as the beer warms.  The hops and a slight alcohol bite hits towards the swallow.  The finish features a wonderful lingering sweet coffee aspect.  One of those porters that to me shows how good and understated foreign examples of this style can be.

Poured from a 500ml bottle into a pint glass, very dark with a thick tan head. The aroma was strong and sweet with  notes of malt and fruit. I tried this one pretty warm so a lot of flavors came out. As promised there were notes of roasted malt, chocolate and dark fruit with a creamy mouthfeel. I definitely picked up on the tobacco taste and unfortunately that is not a flavor I enjoy. Definitely a complex and well made porter, just not to my taste.

[172-20061231] 1pt0.9floz. Aroma reminds me of glazed ham, raisins and figs and Christmas Eve dinner. Dense, dark brown body with a medium-lasting light brown creamy head. Roasted fruity raisin figs continue in flavour plus some roasted bandaid. Medium-full body. Interesting blending but doesnt make me think of beer -- would like to re-rate later.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 Re-rate....Aroma is fruity, with spicy hops. Oh and there is definitely tobacco making an appearance. Very nice. Big chocolate on the first sip. Low carbonation. Beautiful oily texture with a bitter finish. The funky tobacco and leatherey flavors work well with the chocolate and hint of smoke. After taste settles in with hints of fruit. This a beautiful porter.

Pours an oily black with a light tan head.  A little smokey, dark malts, light chocolate.  Kind of sweet, smoky, a little bacon, and roasted malts.  What is this?  Kind of tastes like a mix of a dopplebock and a lighter stout.  Wierd porter. Pretty interesting.  Not bad.  Not great.

(500ml bottle) Pours a medium, white foamy head with an opaque body. Nose of medicine, plums, chocolate extract and cherry port. Flavour of salty Finnish licorice, port and deep roasted malt. Unbelievably well done. Gotta love the collaboration Giles Dennis and Garrett Oliver. Many thanks to Blankboy for sending this my way.

500(?)ml brown bottle from Florians in Auburn.  Completely opaque black body with only a thin film of light tan head.  Smells of burnt and caramel malts with hints of black licorice.  Burnt malt, caramel malt, coffee and chocolate flavors dominate with just a hint of black licorice on the finish (along with coffee flavor).  Full bodied, almost to the point of chewiness.  Bears some similarity to Brooklyn Black Chocolate Stout IMO, though lighter in body and alcohol slightly, and a bit more complex.  Fantastic.  The great mouthfeel and complex array of flavors make this beer a clear winner.  Ill be getting it again - a new favorite porter!

The aroma has raspberry and red wine.  Flavor is sour and the carbonation is almost nil.  Sweet and malty, after the initial sourness.  i didnt get the complexity promised by the description, but it is much more complex and interesting than most porters.  Draught at Town Hall, 1/26/2007.

On tap at the Town Hall.  Pours a nice dark brown with a medium tannish brown head.  The aroma is that of sweet toffee bourbon characteristics.  The flavor is malty sweet, but carries a little bit of tart citric acidity.  I am not sure if the line was infected or if this is how it is supposed to taste(soured), but I love it.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of Hogtownharry: Poured a light black color ale with a big foamy head with good retention and lacing. Aroma of black chocolate is very enticing with some nice English malt also noticeable. Taste of lightly sweet chocolate malt is very good and dominated the taste spectrum. Body was slightly watery with some medium carbonation. This was a very good beer but it is lacking a little something to be truly great.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 Bottle from Whole Foods in Chapel Hill. Pour is darkness with 3/4 inch tan head. Big aroma: dark fruits, leather,  chocolate, molasses, tobacco,  sweet roasted malt.  Creamy mouthfeel with lots of sweet malts and dark fruit flavors. Much sweeter than any of the porters I have tried. Kind of lighter body than I am used to as well.  The sweetness kind of overpowers the roastiness which is a little bit of a turnoff for me.  Must drink a different porter now for comparison. Strange, but drinkable brew.

Bottle, I believe courtesy of HogTownHarry. Black body with a small tan head that fades. Aroma of mild roast, dark fruits, raisins, figs (?)  and muted cocoa or hot chocolate notes. Flavour of dark fruit with a dry toasty malt in the finish that occassionally flashes glimpses of cold coffee like bitterness. Average palate could stand to be more full for the style. Alcohol is seemingly non-existent. Interesting, bit heavy on the tastebuds but very interesting.
Pitch black with a thin tan head.  Sweet malty aroma.  Bready and caramelly, a bit on the thinner side.  Bit of chocolatey swirl ... nice little porter.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Thick tan head fades very quickly. Very dark brown, opaque body. Aroma is strange: molasses, marshmallow, caramel nougat, must, graham cracker. Taste: baking chocolate, grass, pickles, sour malts. Also quite nutty with a sweet tobacco dipped in Tennessee whisky. Very heavy on the palate, full bodied. Sweet finish, long finish, pleasant and different.
Dark black with little head.  Very roasty, choclate taste.  Leaves a good impression on the palate.  Solid beer.

500ml bottle.  Aroma:  lots of dark fruit with a prominent grapiness which also carries a light sourness, chocolate, toasted nuts, strong malt sweetness with some molasses, cream, and a light spiciness. Appearance:  Dark brown in color.  Light tan head was full and creamy with good retention.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Dark fruits come through strong again (grapes, raisins, plums), Chocolate, toasted nuts, a sweet spiceiness, cream.  Finishes sweet but not cloying.  Alcohol is noticeable, but helps pull everything together.    Palate:  Medium-full bodied and creamy.  Moderate-low carbonation.  Some light alcohol warming in rear of mouth.  Overall:  A great porter in the english tradtion, albeit with a bit more alcohol.  Good flavors and a great mouthfeel really make this one nice to drink.

black with a large brown head.  lightly roasty aroma.  very sugary with the consistency of maple syrup.  dark caramel and roast flavors.  creamy velvety mouthfeel.  low carbonation.  sweet and thick(like all j.w. lees beers).  what a great brewery!

Strong malty aroma, filled also with molasses and very sweet.  The mouthfeel is great - chewy and thick, meaty...Strong nuttiness in the flavor - maybe they added lots of sugar, because this is actually a very sweet porter.  Heavy on the lactose.  The somewhat higher alcohol content is very-well hidden.  Weird finish, a bit metallic and too sweet.

Dark brown, nearly opaque, with a small ring of tan lace - quite an interesting aroma, that starts out heavily vinous, with a nearly tannic tartness, followed by mildly sweet malts and a hint of smoke - the flavor begins with a semi-dry, red wine/port-like character that is more consistent with certain barleywines than with porters - Im liking that...a lot - some caramel and chocolate sweetness swell up from beneath that, along with some mild roasted/smoked malts - slight acidity, and a bit of coffee and tobacco near the lingering, semi-sweet finish - a bloody brilliant beer.

500 ml bottle.  Very dark brown beer with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of heavily toasted malt, dark chocolate, and molasses.  Great dark malt complexity.  Brown sugar along with a hint of lactic tartness.  Flavour also shows heavy toast, dark malt, caramel, chocolate and a heavy earthiness throughout.  Warming also brings up a subtle smokiness that Im really digging.  Slightly leathery and tobaccoish as well.  Beautiful brew with all the dark malts, dark fruit, dark smoke, and just a touch of tartness to balance it all.
Bottle: Dark brown pour with a small off white head. Aroma of brown sugar, chocolate, and some dark fruits. Flavor, chocolate, fruits and some spice. Very smooth mouthfeel. Pretty solid.

Manchester Star Ale - I added this picture here on RB I dont know that it is the right beer Im putting the rating under the Porter anyhow. 

 Thanks to some fellow RateBeerian for sending this beer my way, many moons ago! 
 Beer pours a dark shade brown, nearly black, with edges of crimson. The aroma is massively juicy! Dark pit fruits radiate from the depth; plums, fig, dates, plums, apple and pears. There is an enormous chewing tobacco like fruity /spiciness that are blended into a chocolaty experience. This is a very unique experience. I havent had much like it the beer reminds me of an English Barley Wine or English strong Ale.

Bottle from Bello Vino, Ann Arbor. Pours a very nice dark ruby-brown with a small tan head. Great aroma, sweet and roasty, with hints of fruit and smoke. Soft, silky mouthfeel. Wonderfully complex flavour - notes of chocolate, coffee, sour cherry, tobacco, licorice and smoky malt. Amazing stuff!
A very tasty brew, hints of cola and raisin with a very very licorice finish, a nice sweetness and pleasing bite accompany each swallow.

from the bottle. poured black with mahogany tint to it with a tan head. aroma a slight sourness comes out, than roasted malts, bitter chocolate, brown sugar as it warms the alcohol pops out along with some dark fruits. flavor, plums, and orange, molasses, some smoke, port wine. chocolate, nutty. a nice dry finish enjoyed this one

25.09.06  50ml bottle.  Deep and slightly hazed cola brown, almost black, with small but lasting dark tan head.  Aroma is rich and savory with good amounts of mineral, some peat, leather, brine, and plum.  Chocolate presents only moderately in the nose.  The flavor is almost exactly as described on the label, which is most unusual.  Strong notes of tobacco, prune, richly booze soaked raisins.  The alchohol is definitely a pleasant component of this beer, a quality witch the folks at JW Lees seem to have down pat.  Long finish brings the emergence of some floral and fruity hops to balance out the earthy notes of the mid-section.  Medium-full bodied throughout.  Much less sweetness than expected.  Very pleasant beer, but tough to deal with the five dollar price tag.

Dark brown coffee color. Diminishing head, little bit of lace. Nose of chocolate, citrusy hops, wine, caramel, earth, dark breads, toffee and maybe hint of brown sugar, licorice and others. Medium-full body, fairly creamy feel, low carb level. Very soft in mouth, a bit of chalkiness but thats nitpicking.  Lots of sweet, mild chocolate winey notes. Really digging in, you find smokey notes, plummy/other dark fruit flavors and more. Understated bitterness at the end takes an edge off the sweetness. Alcohol never tasted only felt:) This is a gorgeous brew, subtle, full of depth and class. I will revisit this many times over I am sure. 

Reminds me of a less vinous sammy smith taddy.  Excellent.

Pint bottle pours black with a nice tan creamy head that stays well and laces the sides of the glass.  Aromas of dark fruit, raisins, molasses, and mild roast.  Flavor is good roasted and malty upfront with definite prune and raisin flavors finding their way behind that.  Also a good amount of molasses in this one and a bit of tobacco as well.  I didnt notice the alcohol at all medium bodied and easy to drink for a 7.3% porter.  Light bitters on the dry finish.  Pretty strong porter here.
Bottle sampled with stegosaurus. pours dark with a tan head. aroma of roast, fruit, and caramel. The flavor is caramel, roast, and bitter. Good beer.

Great nose of ripe fruit, mostly raisins.  Smooth, full mouthfeel.  Differs from other strong porters Ive had.  It is more restrained in malts than Ive come to expect - this I like.  Finish is this beers weekness - its all booze.  Alcohol overwhelms the other flavors by far.  Id have this again, maybe colder to see if that takes care of the boozey finish.

J.W. Lees Manchester Star Ale
English Pint bottle
Unknown bottling, savoured 08/06.
Medium pour in an English pint.

Poured black with a slight dark brown rim, with a mostly lasting fizzy 1 inch mocha head.

Smelt of roasted grain and molasses, a hint of fruit.

Taste was smokey and raisiny upfront, with a sweet and sour and bitter body, like a slightly creamy dark coffee roast.   Finish was above average length, with the bitterness holding on tight, a hint of fruit and tobacco, and the alcohol showing through.  Mouthfeel was creamy and lively.

Overall, a great sweet porter that is bold and complex, whose only flaw may be that the different flavors that are thrown at the drinker are unbalanced and haphazard.

Notes: This could be cellared for a 1/2 year to a year.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark with a small tan head. Aroma of roast, citrus, fruit, caramel, and molaases. The flavor is sweet, roast, caramel, molasses, citrus, fruit, and a good hoppy bitterness. Good body, good brew.

500 ml bottle, via ross.  Pours a clear dark mahogany with a very fizzy and quick disappearing chocolate brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate malt and caramel primarily with lesser notes of dark fruits, roast, and alcohol.  Flavor is loaded with caramel and a syrupy sweetness up front.  Some chocolate and fruitiness also.  Finish is sweet with caramel and toffee.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and a little cloying due to all of the caramel.  Carbonation is fizzy and foams in the mouth.  Overall, just too sweet for me.  Almost crosses the line into a Baltic Porter with all the caramel.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head.   Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, and rich dark chocolate.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and citrus.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, Harrys bottle. Pitch black, small tan head.  Molasses and smoke aroma - wow really complex - also earthy, leather, cola. And to top it off, some fresh almost wheat like malt at the end.  Very sweet taste - lots of that complex aroma shows itself here too.  Like a foreign stout, but lighter and more porter like.  Chocolaty.  Pipe tobacco aroma and taste is a decent way to describe it.  No hint of alcohol.  Quite simply one of the finest beers I have ever tried.

From a 500 ml. narrow neck brown bottle with a blurb on the back label, no bottled/freshness date, sampled at cellar temperature.

Made a good appearance, poured a blackish brown with a foamy light tan head that settled into a thin lacing, good porter carbonation.

Had a tasty porter nose, chocolate, plums and sour cherries, a nice roastiness with whiffs of smoke and alcohol.

A crisp, slick and creamy smooth full bodied mouthfeel, good porter drinkability.

Delicious tasting, a crisp roasted maltiness with a little burnt bitterness, chocolate, nutty, plums and oranges and a dry port wine-like finish with a little woodiness.

One of the better porters Ive had, quite tasty and balanced, from a world class brewery.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a dark ruby-brown, almost black,  with a spare diminishing foamy off-white head. Aroma is roasty, earthy and fruity with some smoke, cola and leather -- quite interesting. Very nice flavour of roasted malt, chocolate, molasses, dark fruit, wood and alcohol. Medium bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel. This was quite the surprise at our tasting, we had no idea it would be this good -- this is a fantastic Porter!

Never would have thought this was a porter- more of an english strong ale or something similar.  Yes it does pour very dark- almost black with ruby-red highlihgts, and no head, low carbonation.  Aroma really doesnt have much chocolate malt like you would expect in a porter, but rather it is dominated by a strong fruity ester profile- plums dates and raisins.  Since this has been aged for over a year now, it shows some signs of oxidation including a bit of wet paper and cardboard in the aroma which mix well with the fruits.  Falvor is fruity as well, with some thick caramel malts anda slight nutty, smokey and even some medicinal characteristics.  Body is medium, but seems a bit weak as it warms but finishes relatively smooth.  Pretty good I guess for a "strong porter" yet not anywhere near a baltic porter for sure.  English strong ale!

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2007 Bottle (500ml).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle.  Poured almost black with ruby highlights, smallish tan foamy-rocky head.  Syrupy overroast malt aroma, dark fruits, thickly sweet, very oily - molasses and nuts; interesting, I get the vinous character as it warms, with prune, plum and sour cherry.  Taste - strongly malty and tart fruit, very thick and dark, not bitter, not overtly alcoholic, I get the leather and tobacco notes, thank you to the description for resolving that.  Mouthfeel is thick, syrupy, sweet and acidic, with a long fruity tart overroast malt finish.  Stunning.  I have another bottle of this, I WILL enjoy it.

Ah, these chewy and astringent English beers, Im not a huge fan (although, Ill rate within style as best as possible). If you like English styles and porters, then youll LOVE this one. Poured a dark brown with reddish edges, nice initial head, and pretty good lacing all the way down. Flavors were complex and changed as it warmed during consumption. Definite dark fruit influence, nutty, light roasted/smoke flavors (tobacco works for me), and then molasses. Pretty tasty, but that chewy mouthfeel and slight acidic and astringent mouthfeel, I just long for a complete fermentation here, conversion of all that wasted malty stuff left behind. Oh well, an enjoyable brew, but it has so much more potential.

500 ml bottle poured a clear dark mahogany with a small dissapating brown head. Aromas of bitter chocolate, light coffee, hints of plum and vanilla. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark chocolate, toffee, plum, light smoke and hints of tobbaco with a smooth lingering bittersweet finish.

I was really quite surprised to see that this beer is listed as a porter. Lovely reddish-brown body with a sweet, roasty nose, my first that was rauchbier. Guess not. Leaving aside its official designation, this is a fine English ale thats heavy on roastiness.

Dark brownish red color with not much of a head at all.  Smells malty, sweet, fruity, and roasted.  Taste is very similar, but it is almost like they took a weak version of Harvest ale and weakened it some, and threw some roasted malts in to make it different.  This was one that I had to choke down for the first few ounces, then it came to me.  Beer becomes much more drinkable the more it is consumed, however it is initially way too sweet.  This could be considered more of an after dinner drink than a porter.  Not bad, just not the best porter I have had by any stretch of the imagination.
Pours dark reddish brown with a tan head.  Flavors are dry, roasted malt with a slight hop finish.  The aroma is musty and malty.  Surprising light on the tongue but very enjoyable.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Nice dark brown pour with a thick and creamy tan head. Aroma is loaded with roasted and toasted chocolate malts, some alcohol, and some hops. Didnt know it was as high in alcohol as it really is. Definitely didnt taste it. Flavor begins with a roasted chocolate and malt flavor with a slight hint of dark fruits toward the middle and a nice and dry finish. Aftertaste is a little roasty and bitter. Quite a nice porter.

Dark brown with a foamy head and spotty lacing. Roasty and chocolate aromas with some bitter notes. Flavor of figs that is slightly vinous. Earthy and chocolate as well. Medium body finishing with notes of chocolate.

This bottled brew poured a very large sized frothy head of finely sized mostly diminishing light brown colored bubbles that left behind an opaque dark brown colored body.  The aroma was mildly vinous sweet malty and hoppy.  The mouth feel was smooth from start to finish with a mild vinous aftertaste.   The flavor contained deep dark chocolate malt dark malt and hop notes.

pours like oil. medium off white head that dissapates. aroma is yeasty with roasted malt, and some hints of raisins. taste is chocolate, caramel, some vanilla and mocha. really really nice, I think this is up there with anchor. nice and creamy, delicioso!

UPDATED: APR 21, 2006 Tap at The Old Toad, Rochester. Aroma was pretty thin and non-existant. A little bit of roasty and fruitiness if any. Flavor was surprisingly malt-fruity, with only a touch of complexity. Sweet orange and tobacco.

Almost black in color with just a little brown showing around the edges of the glass. Wonderful chocolate aroma with a sweet malty background. First thing I notice in the flavor is dark chocolate which is followed by a lovely tobacco taste which Im really stoked about. I recently quit smoking and this beer has the taste that I get from smelling a freshly opened pack of Springwater cigarrettes. The kind of taste that you feel in the back of your throat. Wow I needed that. Theres a little bit of citrusy tang in the finish as well. Mouthfeel isnt as undercarbonated as other JW Lees stuff that Ive tried. Still smooth in the mouthfeel. This one sorta blew me away.

(16.9 oz bottle: Obtained May 05 in trade with goldtwins, thanks Larry!) Well, just like Harvest Ale, this is pretty damn sweet.  But unfortunately, Manchester Star comes off as sugary and fruity sweet rather than malty sweet.  Loads of dark fruits like raisins and prunes, some processed molasses, but the mild roast and bitterness is almost totally shoved in the dark closet by the sweetness, and if not for the smokiness in the finish, this would be a one-dimensional beer if ever there were one.  But personally, if a beer had to be one dimensional, sweet is preferable to many other things, but I still crave some balance here.  Likewise, the nose is all dark, sweet fruit, a bit earthy perhaps.  Medium bodied and gently carbonated, but without anything to balance the beer, its on the cloying side.  Dark brown in color with some transparency at the edges.  The quarter-inch layer of light-tan head dissipates fully in about 15 to 20 seconds.  Lacing is non-existent, obviously.  Needs more of something -- more roast, some hops, a touch of sourness -- to give it balance, but I still find this quite enjoyable.  Could be so much better though...

(draft) Smelled like snot, but that might have been because I was developing a cold. Served too warm for my tastes, and I almost never say that. I very creamy and smooth chocolatey porter. It contains more alcohol than Id have guessed. Id like to try this again once they get the cooler fixed.

Bottle. Medium sized tan fizzy head that mostly diminished, minimal lacing, mostly opaque, carbonated, and a dark brown-almost black hue with some ruby peeking in. Malty, caramel, chocolate, roasty, sweet, and dark fruit nose and pretty much mimicked in the flavor. Smooth, thin mouthfeel. Light body.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2006 Wow, really impressed with this one. Poured into a crown-viking imperial pint glass. An off-white head forms and settles to a velvety blanket that perches itself atop the beer for a short time...

Enough with the poetry. I absolutley love this beer. I am usually a nut for porters and this is spot on. The dark-reddish hue that seems to entrance the imbiber. Winey notes of caramel apple and minerals spiral into a smoky english malt body. Just enough hops on to bitter and work with the judicious carbonation to give a snappy finish. Was the water Burtonized???

Who cares, the only thing that sucks is the price, but I think its well worth it.







Rerating, couldnt help myself, had to have another.  Same as before, but after smelling my roomates pipe, I can definantly see the cavendish.

This beer offers an aroma of dates blended with roasted nuts.  It is black in color with a mild head and decent lacing.  This thin solution spreads well throughout the mouth leaving a nutty taste that fades to a nice sweet date taste as it lingers.

Aroma has lots of dark fruit sweetness and some low intensity roasted malt aromas. Deep black with a quickly diminishing head that compresses to a fine dime thin line. Fore is both malty and fruity with lots of prune and raisin and a bit of molasses for good measure. The alcohol is unoticeable. Tobacco elements do come out, but only as it warms a good bit. Found it quite tasty.

This porter pours a dark brown color from a 500ml bottle. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is chocolate malt, vanilla, cocoa and sweet. A medium bodied porter. Malts are chocolate and coffee. Touch of fruitiness, grape perhaps? Touch of floral hops. Nice balance. Kind of fruity tasting for a porter, but there is a nice crisp dry finish. Nice carbonation. Hides the 7.3% alcohol well. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Bottle purchased at Manchester Wine and Liquors in Manchester, CT.  An appropriate beer for the location.  I can smell this beer from 2 feet away.  Lots of sweet, sugary vanilla and brown sugar notes in the nose.  Closer inspection reveals a more toasted aroma with a bit of dried fruit vinousness.  I do get a bit of shoe leather, though.  Mostly opaque dark brown/black with a light tan head that is pretty small and quickly dissipating.  Starts a bit cigar and chocolate like with a  middle that is kind of rubbery with some toasted matls and a roasted finish.  Definitely unique.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2007 Black Coloring with Sandy Ring.  Rich Malty Tang Aroma..  Smooth Grapey Sweet Taste...Light Alcohol and Lightly Dry Mouthfeel. Easy One to Enjoy.

Rerated @ Town Hall 9-18-07

Black Color with Sandy Tan Head.  Medium Bodied with a Grapey Juice Like Mouthfeel.  Tart and Fruit Notes Come Out Right Away with Some Subtle Coffee Roasts..Bittersweet Aftertaste with some Dry Hopping.  Like a Mix of a Porter and a Sour Ale.

Pours with a two-finger light tan head that fades quickly leaving no lace.  Black - totally opaque.  Light carbonation, medium-heavy bodied.   Nose is molasses/raisin.  Starts sweet, didnt really notice the hops, smooth molasses finish, excellent porter.  Pricey, $6.99 for a 500ml bottle from Julios Liquors, Ma.

Pint bottle, snifter.  Small, tan head required a forceful pour to be created and is thusly made of larger bubbles and quickly diminishing.  Deep brown-black hue reveals a deep shade of clear ruby when held to a light.  Rich malty notes of caramel, chocolate, roasted, and dark grain breads are met and balanced by rich esters of plums, raisins, molasses, port, light smoke and tobacco, and brown sugar.  Flavor is a dead-on translation of the aroma.  Starts rich and inviting with roasty, caramel and chocolate notes.  Those elements fade into a smooth brown sugar and dark fruit finish. Acidity is pleasing low throughout with only the slightest tart twang to the finish.   Flavors roll on forever after this one is swallowed.  Body is medium full with a tongue-drenching velvety texture which lingers due to the thankfully soft carbonation.  Truly decadent, would love to pair this one with a cigar.

Deep garnet with a thick, tight-packed head.  Chocolate and caramel dominate the nose.  Sweet, malty aroma full of delictable goodness.   Pungent raisins, molasses, brandy soaked plums, whole grain bread and a toouch of licorice all mesh nicely with the caramel and cocoa.  Nice, full, rounded body with soft, subtle carbonation.  The flavors are splendid.  Sweet, full malt with rounded elements of sweet, roasted, lightly smoked and fruity.  Really, a tasty, superb beer with  layered malt and excellent complexity.  A nice, drinkable, celebration style beer.  Well done.
Deep dark brown color with a creamy dark head. Yeasty aroma with a sweet, chocolatey taste with a hint of vanilla left on your lips.  A complex and enjoyable beer.

Out of a bottle, thanks rich for another great tasting.  Aroma  of nice mixture of smoke,coffee and hops.  Poured a nice dark brown.  Flavor was quite enjoyable,  started as cold cappucino with hint of vanilla releasing to its hops. Palate was good thin and sweet but finished delicately. Overall this was very good and had a definitive british character as well.

Dark brown with a ruby ring, a small beige head and very little lacing.  Roasted malt aroma with hints of toffee and molassas.  Smooth, medium bodied, slightly oily mouthfeel.  Modestly hopped, sweet malt taste with a semi-dry, earthy finish.

pours a deep dark brown, , coffee colored head sitting on top.  aroma is lots of chocolate, some coffee, and some citrusy hops.  flavor is very complex, lots of chocolate, lip smacking vanilla, a bit of cappuccino and a grassy undertone.  a very sweet finish.  there  is a bit of smokiness at the very end, but the sweetness coats your tounge and lips and makes for a great aftertaste.  the body is a little thin, but it doesnt take anything away from this excellent flavored beer.

Appears black in the glass, with a small, poorly developed light tan cream.  Very light malt aroma, with a hint of espresso (with cream), roast and chocolate along with a touch of charred raisins and a hint of leather.  Flavor is really rich and malty, quite unique in its composition.  Hints of chocolate covered plums, salty cashews and a light hint of coffee.  Light in body, but with a fitting texture and a moderate hop finish.  Very tasty porter, but lacking aromatically.  Still though, to be drinking this in 1884...

Mahogany tinted chestnut. Quickly fleeting tan bubbles settle to a foamy collar. Saliva inducing nose of toffee pudding drizzled with caramel and topped with dates. Touch of nougat, prunes, and black licorice. Softly carbonated. Early cheek-buckling flash of dried plum acidity is cushioned by an extremely soft flavor profile of figs and fruitcake. Slight char tease is negated by  rich nougat and taffy-dipped prunes, which impart more chewiness. Short-lived soggy fruitiness lessens some of the richness, but is soon lifted by a mid-burst of airiness/plastic, black pepper, and bittersweet chocolate. Quite wet, but sufficiently full. Immensely complex, with an imperceptible alcohol presence, to boot. Derives its complexity from a remarkably unique yeast character, as theres very little emphasis on roast, and merely a pinch of chalkiness. Sweetness heightens at the finish, as a hard mineral underlay harmonizes with ghostlike whispers of toffee pudding, meaty blackstrap molasses, port, and burnt sugar. Could stand to be less sweet and plasticy, but the alcohol is well masked, the yeast character fits like a glove, and the aroma is out of this world. One of the most characterful Porters in existence. Period.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Chocolate, dark fruit aroma. Taste reminded me somewhat of Rogues black obi. Dark fuit, dryness. Good brew.

Almost no head and basic blackish brown for pour.  Very sweet Chocolate toffee malt taste.  Very smooth and creamy with almost no hop.  I have never had porter this sweet and complex in taste and aroma before.

Pours almost black with red highlights if you hold it to a light.  Tan head recedes quickly but leaves a bit of lace.  Aromas are caramel, molasses, brown sugar, and yeast.  Taste is a thick, toffee and chocolate homage to sweet malt with hints of espresso, raisins, currants, prunes, dates, chocolate, and licorice.  Mouthfeel is luxuriously chewy and creamy.  Overall, its a sweet malty concoction with only a hint of hops.  This is a malt-lovers ale.

I did not notice this was from J.W.Lees. Not a huge fan of teres. Nose was chocolate, and dark fruits. The taste was chocolate and some surprise spices. I got hints of smokiness. Smooth finish and kind of watery for the ABV.

J W Lees has some impressive brews.  This wasnt up to the standards of their Harvest Ales but it was a good drink.  Dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Aroma was subtle notes of chocolate, caramel, prune, seasoned pipe bowl, and orange zest.  Full bodied, smooth and creamy.  Flavorful but not as rich as the aroma.  This was very much a traditional English porter and well done as such.

500 ml big brown bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a deep espresso brown, with red highlights around the edges. Thin, fast fading tan colored head. Left a small ring of bubbles around the rim of the glass.Aromas are of sweet pipe tobacco, cigars even.Slight rum notes along with earthy hops in the background. Slightly rustic. Flavors are of roasted malts, some sweet coffee notes, and a fast fading hoppy bite. Well rounded, thin on the body for such a high ABV beer. Finished slightly sweet, but not cloying.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2009 Bottle.

Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, fully lasting.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (chocolate, roasted grain, caramel), with light notes of old leather and earth, hint of cardboard.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, creamy/velvety texture, lively/soft carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

The aroma doesn’t rock me like it did back in 2005, but it’s still a luxurious, creamy, well-balanced beer in the mouth. Good stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2005 Marcellos Wine Market, Baton Rouge, La. Sweet, pipe tobacco like aroma. Dark brown, fading to black with a tight off-white head. Flavor is pleasing with sweet pipe tobacco notes, some licorice and bittersweet chocolate. Delicious. The mouthfeel is just thick enough. Great find!

Dark brown with ruby edges and a quickly fading beige head. Nice aroma of roasted malt, milk chocolate and a hint of red wine. Very sweet and syrupy. Notes of roasted malt, wine, plum, raisin, brown sugar and chocolate. Too sweet for me, not much bitterness. Medium body, smooth texture and subtle carbonation.

What a good aroma here - dark roasts, chocolate, earthyness, dark fruits.  Dark black heavy looking body, had a nice chocolate malt with moderate roasts, finished a little sweet and partially dry.  This is tasty - worth picking up ocassional bottles.

Very dark black color with a small off-white head. Nice sweet dark fruit and  mild roasty aroma. Very sweet plum, brown sugar and little roasted coffee flavors, with a dry hoppy bite in the finish.  A little thin and watery, but nice flavor!

Deep, dark black color with ruby highlights and a small, soapy off-white head. The aroma was quite good...old leather (maybe tobacco), roastiness, plum, other sweet fruits. The flavor was not as interesting...way too sweet...sugary...with a slightly roasty background. The feel was thin and watery with a semi-wet finish. Thanks BBB63 for this!

Nearly opaque black with ruby edges. Small soapy light tan head that dissapates quicky. The aroma consists of cocoa, light citrus, and a little bit of sourness. The flavor is interesting, toffee, cocoa, citrus, and some dark fruits. Nice. The palate is medium with a lager-like feel to it. A tad too sweet in the end.

Nice black body and a tan head on top.  Aroma is a light malt scent and not much else.  Flavor is a good warm roasted malt taste, with a good sweetness.  Palate is smooth, very smooth for a porter.  The alcohol is well hidden in this brew.

Dark, blackish brown, rapidly and completely fading head.  Aroma of molasses, bit of chocolate, faint fruit and roastiness.  Mouth is a blend of chocolate, molasses, caramel, and dark fruits - mostly plum.  Hint of apricot.  Interesting, and quite enjoyable.  Well done.

The dark brown body is topped by a fleeting head that retreats to a ring around the glass. Malty, earthy aroma. You get a bit of plum and prune and an earthiness that Im guessing is what others are calling tobacco, although I dont really get the tobacco myself. The flavor is sugary sweet in the middle, but finishes surprisingly light. Interesting beer.

Small tan head that is short lived settling to a thin ring, a touch of stringy lace hanging around. A near black brew almost opaque. Light roast in the nose, licorice and chocolate, faint fruitiness. Medium bodied brew. Medium sweet malts on the palate, fruity with an unusual spiceyness, notes of caramel, chocolate and touch of toffee. Finish is lightly sweet and roasty.

Bottle from Goldtwins.  Pours a near black color with just a bare hint of red/ruby showing when backlit.  Smallish white head forms and fades to ring the edge and leaves some slight lacing.  Aroma is of roasted grain, a little bit of molasses and a faint background of some earthy hops.  Medium bodied going on full bodied.  Flavor is for a quick instant very sweet and fruity, a sour/bitter streak comes in and balances the sweetness out nicely.  Long finish of hop and malt balance.  Slightly drying.  Quite a different porter but very well done.

This is really fruity; so-called dark fruits like plum and prune abound. Malty. Not a session brew but very interesting. Sweeter than another old, traditional porter (the Elwood Flag). This has a super slick, velvety body. Served by Alex at Belmont Party: room temp in clear plastic with JCW - good times.

text: Bottle: Pours a opaque black with a fading head but always enough left to keep a good lace on my snifter. The aroma is unique for a porter, lots of tobacco notes and strange lambic like yeast twang. Oh there is the roasted malts, plum fruit esters, and some nutty nature. The taste starts equally unique with a streak of tangy and ripened fruits on top of some aged powerful malt expression.  Wow, I get a hint of earthy funk on the finish, almost vinous. The feel is thin but I think that was done for a reason to increase drinkablity, still a touch sticky after all is said and done. Bravo old school, different for most and that is a good thing. I dig it and need to get some more.
Black color with no head.  Sweet malt aroma and taste with a hit of chocolate and bitterness.  It seems there might be something along the grape/prune/plum line too.

(500ml bottle) Clear dark brown/garnet with fairly small tan head.  Aroma is medium sweet, tobacco, plum, caramel, light chocolate.  Taste is sweet, chocolate, caramel, some raisin, orange, light tobacco.  Medium body, lightly carbonated.  A very easy-drinking beer, although a wee bit cloying.
Murky brown without much head. Taste is tobacco, caramel and toffee. Lightly carbonated with a thin ner than expected body.
Dark brown with ruby highlights. Almost no head. Sour roasted aroma. Balanced apple juice and roasted malt flavour with some chocolate. Has an attractive flavour profile.

Very dark brown.  Chocolatey, citric aroma.  Sweet and sour flavour is fruity, chocolatey, and complex.  Sorry if I didnt pick up the moist Cavendish tobacco...my bad...but its a nice rendition of old school porter, a style I almost always enjoy.

Dark brown with a light fizzy head and small rings of lacing. Nose of light creamy roast and sweet fruits such as cherry or apple. The flavor is creamy, some chocolate, nice medium body. Finishes smooth, a little sweet and maybe even green, but a good homage to traditional porters.

Wine/port nose with chocolate and dark fruit hints; sweet, malty chocolate and cola flavor; plummy/prune fruitiness, soy-sauce, cola and nut notes; mild roasty dryness in the finish, smooth palate and fairly viscous, slightly acidic; well hidden alcohol. A bit sweet, but I really like this.

Bottle. Black hue with small rocky light brown head that diminished quickly. Aroma was heavy of sweet and roasted coffee with a smoke tone. Flavor and body were full and complex with a creamy smooth finish. Good brew.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2005 Nice porter, masking its 7% (my bottle reads 7.3%) ABV under a very smooth drink indeed.  Pouring a rich, earthy dark brown with a short-lived brown head (R.I.P.ing as a halo), this has a deep chocolate & caramel aroma.  The body is medium, approaching watery, but somewhat chewy as well.  The flavor is roasted malt, milk chocolate, some light hopping, all blended together with great skill.  I could porter for this.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a nearly opaque, robust dark brown with a thin coating of light tan head.  Has a sweet, mildly roasty aroma with hints of dark chocolate and plenty of malt.  Starts sweet and sugary with some character reminiscent of a foreign stout.  Has a sticky, cloying finish, but hides the alcohol well.  Could use some more body and more perhaps a little less sweetness to improve its overall drinkability.

Poured a very dark brown to black color with a small quickly dissolving tan head.  Aroma is small mostly lightly roasted malt.  Aroma of a iced cafe mocha.  Flavor is light some coffe, tobacco, and sweet roasted malt.  Starts silky and finishes  mildly acidic.  Light-medium body.  A touch of warming sensation.  Even though 7% this is a refreshing beer...light with a decent flavor.

The Lure:Nutty roastiness and sweet raspberries adorn the milk-chocolate-covered blueberry pie. Roasting chestnuts send messages to the saliva-producing glands.

The Festivities:Roasty bitterness is subdued, as is the oncoming dryness. A slick mouthfeel proliferates the sweet fruitiness within, as dates and chestnuts spread their goodness on the medium-full body. 

Transcendence:Not the shiniest star, but nice to observe nonetheless.

Lightly sourish winey aroma.  Dark malts, hints of earthy (goldingish) and resiny (challengerish) hops.  Tobacco as well.  Salty, rather dry.  Some astringent brown malts.  Bits of coffee and chocolate.   Dry winey/tobacco finish.    Clark nails it when he says salty woodsmoke  not overly smoky, but just a hint.  While this is certainly fine, theres much better out there.  Historical accuracy be damned!

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2006 2005 bottle shared at the 4/17/2005 Montreal tasting. Pours a dark black color, with mahogany brown tinges on the edges of the glass. Tremendously filtered and clear as Ive come to expect from Lees. Light tan head is initially large, but recedes, slowly, to a small covering. Aroma of lipsmacking caramel and toffee, light fudge notes, honeycream, low-bitterness roast, musty, old yeast and some dryish milk chocolate notes. Flavor begins with coffee and salty woodsmoke. Chewy chocolate, vanilla-buttercream and a touch of anise. Finishes with a moderate amount of roastiness, quite a bit of sweet malt and not as much yeast as the nose would have it. Body is medium at best, though for a traditional English porter, (which it isnt) this would be ok. For what it is, I do think its too light of body for all of the wonderful promises it makes on the label, not to mention the 7+ abv. Mouthfeel is quite loose, though a bit of chewy malt can be found. I do like that smoke flavor though. . .

500 ml bottle sipped thankfully with beerbuzzmontreal, ClarkVV, MartinT, tiggmtl, olivier, Rastacouere and Simon at the Farmhouse Ales and More! tasting in Montreal.  Dark root beer translucence, small off-white topping...burnt-baked fruits (peaches, cherries) in the nose, and some sweet chocolate-caramel, quite luscious if it were more expressive...sweet choco-cherry front, soy and dry biscuity malt in the middle, not a whole lot of interest in the finish.  Decent, but I dont get the excitement...

Fruity aroma with some chocolate character and light roasty tones.  Opaque brown body with partial cover and ring of tan head that leaves some light lacing.  Very dry and well-attenuated.  Fairly sweet up front with a hint of dry roastiness and a light soy character.  Medium body with low carbonation.  Bottle sampled with beerbuzzmontreal, ClarkVV, MartinT, muzzlehatch, Olivier, Rastacouere and Simon.
Pours a deep black color with a ring of light brown lace. Aroma and flavor of chocolate and roasted malt. Medium body, dry texture and soft carbonation.

Clearish dark brown, little to no head. Gently fruity and hence a bit vinous nose (grapes, dates, berries). Black pumpernickel feel rather than pure roast. Develops pleasant cigar undertones and light nutty flavours. For 7.3%, this is pretty easy-going, for the better and for the worst.

Poured a brownish red color with a small, light tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, roast, some caramel as well.  Taste was very sweet, lots of caramel malt, nuts, chocolate and roast in the background.

500ml bottle...No head to speak of...opaque black with a bit of brunette highlighting...Aroma is pretty subdued...faintly the sort of smell I associate with dark malts like patent & chocolate...a mellow liquorice sort of roastiness...and tastes a bit like sausage...and weak coffee...OK, quite flat though.

Pours a solid black with a medium tan head that sticks around. Aroma is dark roast, molasses, raisins, and chocolate nibs. Flavor is dark roast, molasses, raisins, and chocolate nibs. A lot like Fullers london porter but with a bit more of a roasted edge.

Bottle. Very dark brown in color with a small, somewhat fizzy, tan head, that settles to a small amount of tiny bubbles in the appearance of an octopus on top. Small isles of lace.  Very gentle nose with only hints of roasted malts, treacle and prunes. Light and smooth on the palate. Pale malt sweetness well balance with a touch of roasted malt and lightly herbal hops. Some fruit cake flavors mid quaff, with dates and raisins. Yes, there does seem to be a mild tobacco component and a touch of oak in the finish. A very relaxing brew. One Im sure will find its way back to one of my glasses.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2005 Bottle. My label calls this "Manchester Star Ale" and states that this is 7.3%. Opaque brown to near black. Small foamy tan head. Light roasted malt, brown sugar, light chocolate notes and light fruity notes. Taste is sweet malts, chocolate, ripened dark fruits, light vanilla notes and caramel. Its an odd mish-mash of flavors and for some reason really works for me. Body is medium and creamy. Light carbonation sharpness.Mild dryness towards the finish. Ends with more caramel and sweet malts, dark fruits, chocolate and light nuttiness. Nice beer! Id love to try this on cask!

Bottle... Right after pouring this beer in my office and heading downstairs to watch the tip-off of the WVU vs Louisville game in the NCAA 2005 Elite Eight, I slipped on the top step of the landing and my butt pounded all twelve steps on the way down to the foyer. Lucky to be alive, but 3/4 of this porter ended up on the stairwell and wall. Biggest mess I have ever seen. Wish it had been water or a Coors light as cleanup will last for hours. My butt will be bruised for weeks. Ended up with glass in hand and held totally upright... thank God! Watching the beer drip down the wall, I can tell that this is an extemely dark porter. Whats left in my glass has a mid-sized, frothy, beige head. Good retention. The nose is of dark chocolate, cola, vanilla and light licorice. Big, malty, chocolatey flavor with a lesser note of molasses. Full-bodied and oily with pillow-soft carbonation. Malty, roasty finish, but remarkably dry at the wee end. Great stuff. I wish I could have enjoyed the entire bottle!

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2005 A small light tan head. The body is black with just the faintest hint of amber light coming through. The aroma is sweet cherries with some vanilla and chocolate. The taste is a very sweet chocolate with caramel. The finish is slightly roasted with walnuts and some coffee. A touch of tobacco and some dried apricots. Very sweet for a porter. Thin bodied. Mattbob may be correct, age should mellow out the sweetness.

Bottle pours like black coffee (brownish black), large frothy sand colored head, average head retention, with fairly attractive lacing.   Subtle roasted malts, a bit of charred wood, apple skin, and wheat bread on the nose.   Very mild dark pitted fruit as well.   Sweet malts, slight coffee... VERY smooth on the tongue.   Medium to full bodied, but while this Porter is quite light on the palate, it is extremely smooth.   Soft hop presense on the finish, sweet & malty, with a nice balance of lightly roasted malts and minor charred wood.   Soft and sensual with a well hidden ABV.   Extremely drinkable.

Bottle.Poured a very dark brown color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma is what gets the attention here.
The combination between the pale and roasted malts is quite amazing. No caramel malts are used but I swear I can smell them, along with dark fruits and chocolate. Very little hops present at first, but they do help with the dry finish. Flavor is everythig I just mentioned and then some. Starts off sweet and smooth with bits of dark fruit and coffee, then finished rather dry. An excellent beer.

Bottle. Deep dark brown in color with a nice tan head. Fruity, roasty, malty aroma. Thick and roasty flavor. Low hop character. Smooth. Roasty and coffee notes. Sweet tasting beer. Well balanced. Full bodied. Enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2005 Bottle. Deep dark brown and clear, tan head. Fruity, roasty, malty aroma. Flavor is thick and malty, with roasty chocolate and coffee characteristics. On the sweet side, with low hops, and high malt bitterness. Fantastice balance with the alcohol well hidden. Dry finish. And Garrett Oliver of Brooklyn helped make this beer as well.
